Here is the simplified text for a learner of level C1:

Shopping habits Ever find yourself leaving a store with more than you intended to buy? Supermarkets use various techniques to encourage you to spend more. A. Fresh and appealing Supermarkets know that customers value fresh produce. They often display it at the entrance or near the entrance, or even have a bakery that fills the store with the smell of freshly baked bread. The store's color scheme may also contribute to this impression, such as using green to evoke feelings of freshness. B. Strategic product placement The location of products in a store is crucial to their success. Supermarkets use computerized stock control to determine which areas of the store are most popular and place high-profit items or quick-selling products there. Manufacturers often prefer shelves at eye level, while "dump bins" with special offers can tempt customers to buy more. C. Placing essentials strategically Supermarkets may place essential items like bread, tea, and sugar in different parts of the store, making customers pass by higher-profit items on the way. Similarly, chain stores may place their best-selling products far from the entrance, relying on customer loyalty to encourage customers to search for them and pass by other tempting products. D. Less is more Chain stores have changed the way they display their products. Next, for example, presents limited fashion items on shelves, giving the impression that the products are exclusive. This is not just about the products themselves, but also about the store design. E. The psychology of shopping Food shoppers are more likely to respond to the overall cost of their shopping trip than individual prices. Supermarkets take advantage of this by stocking a mix of low- and high-markup items. F. The importance of pricing Shoppers are more aware of individual prices in chain stores and may be more price-sensitive. G. Lighting and ambiance Supermarkets and chain stores pay attention to lighting, with chain stores aiming for a natural light effect to show the true color of clothing. Supermarkets use special lighting and mirrors to enhance the appearance of certain foods. H. Guiding customers Many chain stores use different carpeting to guide customers through the store, with a clear path and separate areas for sales. I. In-store promotions As you enter a supermarket, you may be greeted with large, colorful images of food, tempting you to buy. Some supermarkets are even using video screens in their trolleys to advertise products as you shop, aiming to increase sales by around 30%.<|eot_id|>

|end_header_id|>
Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of level C1:

Chris Bonnington, a renowned mountaineer, and Robin Knox-Johnston, a seasoned sailor, teamed up to explore Greenland together. They wrote a book about their adventure, called Sea, Ice and Rock. I had the opportunity to join them on their trip to Greenland, where we sailed and climbed together. I was impressed by Robin's climbing skills, despite being a beginner. He was very steady and calm, even in challenging conditions. I showed him some climbing techniques, and he was eager to learn. During our trip, we faced some difficulties, but Robin was an excellent leader. He consulted everyone before making decisions, which made me feel included in the process. However, I found the sailing part of the trip quite boring, as I'm not used to being at sea for long periods. Robin, on the other hand, enjoyed the sailing and was always tinkering with the engine or fixing things on the boat. When we reached Greenland, I felt a bit useless as I wasn't as skilled as Robin in sailing. I also had to take responsibility for Robin's safety while climbing, which was a challenge. We faced many obstacles, including a difficult climb up the Cathedral, Greenland's highest mountain. Robin was not a natural climber, but he persevered and put his trust in me. We eventually had to turn back, but Robin was understanding and focused on getting the boat through the ice safely. The only time we had a disagreement was when Robin took over the watch on the boat without waking me up. I felt he didn't trust me, but he reassured me that I had misjudged the situation. Through our adventure, I discovered that beneath his tough exterior, Robin was a kind and sensitive person.<|eot_id|>

|end_header_id|>
Here is the simplified text for a learner of level C1:

Apples have been around for thousands of years, with many different varieties. However, the late 20th century is at risk of losing this heritage. 

Prehistoric humans ate apples as far back as 8,000 BC. They would spit out the seeds, which grew into new apple trees. In ancient Britain, people even stored apple halves for winter. These early apples were small and not like the ones we know today.

The Romans brought advanced fruit-growing skills to Britain, including cider-making. They introduced the dessert apple, Decio, which was popular in Roman times. However, most Roman varieties didn't thrive in Britain's climate, and the Norman varieties became more dominant.

In the 13th century, several apple varieties became popular in Britain. The Old English Pearmain was a main dessert apple until the 18th century. The Costard, a cooking apple, was sold in Oxford markets for over 200 years. It gave us the word "costermonger," meaning a street vendor who sells fruit and vegetables.

However, prosperity declined due to droughts, the Black Death, and wars. Fewer apples were produced, and more were imported. It wasn't until Henry VIII ordered his chief fruiterer to visit France and learn about apple cultivation that the industry began to improve.

In the 17th century, apples became so popular that settlers took them to new lands, including Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand. Captain Bligh took apples to Australia, Jan van Riebeeck to South Africa, and the Pilgrim Fathers to America. In North America, John Chapman, also known as Johnny Appleseed, planted apple nurseries from Pennsylvania to Indiana.

In the 19th century, a Quaker farmer discovered a new apple variety, which he named "Delicious." It became one of the most widely grown apples in the world. Another famous apple variety was discovered by Maria Anne Smith, who found a small tree growing in a pile of discarded fruit. She transplanted it and harvested the first major crop of green apples.

Today, apples are grown all over the world, but most commercial apples come from just a few varieties chosen for their red skin or ability to travel well. This has led to a loss of diversity, and many old apple varieties have been lost forever. However, consumers are starting to demand more variety, and it's essential to protect natural diversity for the benefit of all.<|eot_id|>

|end_header_id|>
Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of level C1:

Explore Worldwide offers unique and exciting travel experiences to destinations that go beyond the ordinary tourist routes. Our trips are designed for people who want to immerse themselves in new cultures and environments. We have over 100 original adventures, including tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions, in more than 60 countries around the world. Most of our trips last from one to four weeks and are led by expert guides. Our small groups, averaging 16 people, allow for a more personal and interactive experience.

We use a variety of transportation, including buses, trains, boats, canoes, and even camels, to get to our destinations. This helps us to experience the local culture and terrain firsthand. Our trips cater to people of all ages and abilities, as long as they are reasonably fit and adaptable.

Our trips are divided into eight categories, each highlighting a unique aspect of the experience. These categories include cultural adventures, wildlife and natural history, ethnic encounters, easy/moderate hiking, major treks, wilderness experiences, sailtreks/seatreks, and raft and river journeys.

For example, our cultural adventures take you to destinations like Egypt, Jordan, and India, where you can explore ancient ruins and immerse yourself in local customs. Our wildlife and natural history trips offer opportunities to see animals in their natural habitats, such as on a safari in Africa or a trek in the Himalayas. Our ethnic encounters allow you to meet and learn about local tribes and communities, such as the Tuareg in the Sahara or the Maya in Mexico.

Our easy/moderate hiking trips take you on leisurely walks through scenic countryside, while our major treks are for experienced hikers who want to tackle more challenging terrain. Our wilderness experiences offer the chance to explore remote and untouched areas, such as the Amazon Rainforest or the Sahara Desert. Our sailtreks/seatreks allow you to travel by boat, while our raft and river journeys offer a unique perspective on the world from the water.

At Explore Worldwide, we believe that travel should be a transformative experience that broadens our horizons and deepens our understanding of the world.<|eot_id|>

|end_header_id|>
Here is the simplified text for a learner of level C1:

Richard Nerurkar, a top British long-distance runner, visited the Kenyan high-altitude training camp. The camp is located 10 miles south of Nairobi, at the foot of Mount Kenya, the second-highest mountain in Africa. This beautiful but isolated spot has been Nerurkar's base for winter training in Kenya's Central Highlands for three years. On his fourth trip, he broke his tradition by training with Kenyan runners on their home soil. He was invited by the national team coach after finishing fifth in the World Championship 10,000-metre race. The Kenyan team coach offered him the opportunity to train at the national team camp, where the country's top runners prepare for the World Cross-Country Team Championships.

Training at high altitude increases the production of red blood cells, which improves oxygen-carrying capacity. This has been proven by the success of generations of Kenyan runners. Nerurkar's first African race was also a significant event, as it was the first international cross-country race held on African soil. Despite being humbled by the competition, Nerurkar felt he had not had a bad race. However, he believes that Kenyan success cannot be attributed solely to altitude. Kenyan runners are known for their simple and uncomplicated approach to the sport, as well as their passion for competing.

During his stay at the Kenyan team training camp, Nerurkar discovered the secrets behind their success. The camp is located at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up the southern slope of Mount Kenya, surrounded by beautiful playing fields and dense tropical vegetation. The athletes live in basic dormitories and follow a strict daily routine, which includes three workouts: a morning run, interval training, and a steady run in the afternoon. The daily routine starts at 6:00 am, with a leisurely morning run, followed by a briefing from the coaches. The athletes cover a total distance of about 40 kilometres per day, with a shorter run on Sundays. Life at the camp is uncomplicated, with simple meals and a focus on running.

By the time Nerurkar left the camp, he was even more appreciative of Kenyan success. He realized that it cannot be attributed solely to genetics, upbringing, or altitude. Instead, he believes that the purity and simplicity of the mountainside lifestyle, the gruelling workouts, and the passion for success are the real reasons behind Kenya's dominance in distance running.<|eot_id|>

|end_header_id|>
Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of level C1:

Advertising is in trouble. It's not just because of the recession. The problem is that advertising has failed to keep up with the pace of economic change. Advertisers often focus on mass markets and mass media, but as brands and media have increased, target markets have become more fragmented. This means that even campaigns for big brands rarely target minority audiences.

Think about your own shopping habits. You might buy 30-50 items at a supermarket, but many of these won't be advertised brands. You might buy a few hundred brands over a year, but most of them won't be advertised. Even when you include consumer durables, cars, clothes, and services, it's unlikely you'll buy more than 400 different brands a year. Yet, there are over 9,500 brands advertised. It's clear that most people don't buy most of the brands they see advertised.

When you watch TV, count how many commercials are for brands you buy or might buy in the future. For most people, it's about 6%. The rest are, on the surface, wasted. You might think you're immune to advertising, but you're not. The truth is that nobody buys most of the brands they see advertised. Advertising is inherently wasteful, as people only register a small number of ads and ignore the rest.

However, advertising can still be effective. Millions of ads have proven that it works. Advertising is a cheap way to communicate with large numbers of people, even if it's difficult to know exactly who will respond. The goal is to minimize waste by targeting the right people, but it's impossible to know exactly who will respond. This is different from face-to-face selling, where a salesman can potentially sell to every client. The key to successful advertising is to target the right people and minimize waste.

The most effective way to reach a large number of people may be through mass media, but for advertising to work again, its message needs to be more targeted than ever before.<|eot_id|>

|end_header_id|>
Here is the simplified version of the text, adapted for a learner of level C1:

In Nottinghamshire, there's a remarkable house that's not only environmentally friendly but also surprisingly normal-looking. The house, designed by Robert and Brenda Vale, is known as the 'autonomous house'. It's a self-sufficient home that uses rainwater for washing and drinking, recycles sewage into compost, and generates its own heat from waste and human body heat. The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, have been passionate about environmental design for decades. They wrote a book on green architecture in the 1970s and built this house to demonstrate that it's possible to live in a way that's not detrimental to the environment.

The house is designed to be super-insulated, with triple-glazed windows that keep the noise out. Inside, it's quiet and peaceful, with a warm conservatory that helps to heat the air. The Vales have thought of every detail, from air-locked doors for their pets to draught-proofing throughout the house. They've also designed composting toilets and rainwater tanks to reduce their reliance on mains water.

The house is remarkable for its low-tech design and minimal maintenance. Almost everything was sourced from a local builder's merchant and installed by local craftsmen. The result is a house that's not only environmentally friendly but also affordable to build. Despite its innovative design, the Vales' house is surprisingly warm and comfortable, with a secret that lies in its ability to maintain a consistent temperature without draughts or radiant heat loss.

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of level C1:

Arthur Conan Doyle, the creator of Sherlock Holmes, was known for his rational and scientific approach. However, in 1920, he was convinced that he had found proof of the existence of fairies after seeing photographs taken in a garden. He published the photos alongside an article, acknowledging the fairies as supernatural wonders. It wasn't until 1939 that the two women who took the photos revealed the truth: they had simply cut out fairy pictures from a book and arranged them among the flowers. The results are indeed beautiful, but the simplicity of the trick highlights the fact that the camera is not always truthful. In fact, photography has never been a completely honest medium. From the moment cameras started capturing reality, reality was being altered. Today, we're used to being able to manipulate digital images using computer software, and it's clear that photography has never been a truly innocent art form.

Here is the simplified version of the text for a learner of level C1:

For centuries, iron has captivated human imagination, and blacksmiths have been more than just skilled craftsmen. In the past, they were considered as important as doctors and astrologers, as they were the only ones who could make weapons, armor, and farming tools. Eighteenth-century blacksmiths created intricate ironwork for St Paul's Cathedral, and their sinuous metalwork was a hallmark of French and Belgian Art Nouveau architecture. However, by the late 1960s, blacksmiths had almost disappeared in Britain, as heavy industry no longer needed them, and modern architects rarely used ornate ironwork.

In recent years, there has been a revival of interest in decorative architecture and interior design, and blacksmiths have seen a resurgence in popularity. However, much of the work still looks clichéd, with manufacturers promoting their products as "classical" or "Victorian-style." Fortunately, there are alternatives, and a series of events aims to promote the blacksmithing craft. The first event, an exhibition of forged ironwork by members of the British Artist Blacksmiths Association, has just opened at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey.

According to Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, "We could be at the start of a new Iron Age, as both the general public and blacksmiths have had their eyes opened." Power tools have freed smiths from the drudgery of working over a hot anvil, allowing them to shape and mold the metal with ease. "In short, these artists now have a material that allows them to express themselves," Dawson says.

The exhibition features around 250 pieces, ranging from bookends to a spiral staircase, with prices starting at £90 and going up to four figures. The majority of the proceeds will go to the individual artists, with a percentage retained by the Association to promote good ironwork.

Many of the artists are fascinated by iron, which is a demanding medium that requires skill and patience. Susan May, a jeweler by training, notes that iron is "magical" because it's soft when hot but becomes rigid and unyielding when cool. Ann Catrin Evans' mild steel door-knockers and handles are inspired by the bleak castles of horror movies. "I love the fact that steel is cold and hard," she says. "And the way it feels like it's there forever."

Iron has given humans a sense of security and visual pleasure, and it's likely to remain a popular choice for decorative purposes for the next thousand years, as long as we don't have to look at any more rusty candlesticks.<|eot_id|>

|end_header_id|>
Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of level C1:

I QUIT SMOKING AND EXPECTED PEOPLE TO BE IMPRESSED, BUT ONE COLLEAGUE WAS FURIOUS. 'WHY DIDN'T YOU STOP YEARS AGO?' SHE ASKED. I SUPPOSE MY INABILITY TO EXPLAIN HOW I GAVE UP SMOKING SO SUDDENLY WAS FRUSTRATING. 

I ATTENDED A STOP-SMOKING SESSION, WHICH COMBINED GROUP THERAPY AND HYPNOTHERAPY. IT TOOK PLACE TWO MONTHS AND THREE WEEKS AGO. I DIDN'T INTEND TO QUIT AND DIDN'T EVEN WANT TO. I FELT PRESSURED BY THE ANTI-SMOKING CAMPAIGN, AND I ALSO FELT I DIDN'T NEED TO QUIT BECAUSE I HAD LOW BLOOD PRESSURE AND A HEALTHY FAMILY. 

ON THE DAY I ATTENDED THE SESSION, I WENT ALONG TO WRITE AN ARTICLE ABOUT PEOPLE TRYING TO GIVE UP SMOKING. I SAID I WOULDN'T BE TRYING TO QUIT, AS I WAS ONLY THERE TO WRITE ABOUT IT. THE COUNSELLOR SEEMED TO UNDERSTAND. WE WERE ALLOWED TO SMOKE AS MUCH AS WE WANTED, AND THE ROOM WAS FILLED WITH SMOKE. 

WHEN I WAS ASKED TO SMOKE, I FELT RELUCTANT, AND SO DID THE OTHERS. I REALISED THAT THE IDEA OF QUITTING MADE SENSE INTELLECTUALLY. JUST AS SMOKING HAD BECOME A CHALLENGE, SO QUITTING BEGAN TO FEEL ATTRACTIVE. THE IDEA OF NOT BEING A SMOKER MADE ME FEEL POWERFUL. IT WAS A SECRET FEELING THAT HAD NOTHING TO DO WITH ANYONE ELSE. 

QUITTING WAS EASIER THAN I EXPECTED. THE PHYSICAL CRAVING FOR NICOTINE Faded AFTER A FEW MINUTES, AND I EXPERIENCED IT FOR ONLY A FEW DAYS. I DIDN'T HAVE ANY PROBLEMS WITH WORK, WHICH I THOUGHT WOULD BE THE MOST DIFFICULT THING TO DO WITHOUT SMOKING. 

THE ONLY TIME I STRUGGLED WAS WHEN I WAS POTTERING AROUND AT HOME ON WEEKEND MORNINGS. I MISS MY CIGARETTES, BUT NOT TOO MUCH. I'M COMING TO REALISE THAT SMOKING WAS A WAY TO DEAL WITH BOREDOM. I NOW HAVE TO FIND NEW WAYS TO DEAL WITH SITUATIONS LIKE EATING OUT, WAITING FOR A PLANE, OR BOOKING INTO A HOTEL.<|eot_id|>

To simplify the text for a learner of level C1, I will make minor changes to the language while maintaining the factual content and structure of the passage. Here is the revised text:

Dorothy Hodgkin, the only British woman to win a Nobel Prize, is not a well-known figure in her own country, despite her remarkable achievements. I've been testing people's knowledge of her by asking if they know about her biography. If they don't, I consider it a failure. Why shouldn't people in Britain know about her? She's a remarkable individual, and her life reflects some of the most significant events of the 20th century, including the advancement of women's education and the globalisation of science.

When I started researching her life, I expected to find many scientific biographies. However, I was surprised to find that there were very few, and none of them were about British scientists. I even tried to find a biography of Linus Pauling, a close friend and contemporary of Hodgkin, but it wasn't available. This lack of interest in scientific biographies is not unique to Britain. Many scientists doubt the value of their own biographies, believing that they make dull reading.

However, this view is not justified. Scientists' lives can be just as fascinating as those of artists and writers. The problem is that scientists often avoid media appearances, fearing that they will be perceived as self-promoting. This lack of personal involvement can give a false impression of science and discourage young people from pursuing careers in the field.

Fortunately, this is changing. Contemporary scientists are now more willing to appear in public, and this has helped to make them more relatable. The publishing industry is also evolving, with more scientific biographies and autobiographies being written. These books now explore the personal lives of scientists, including their relationships, family, and personal struggles.

Dorothy Hodgkin's life is a great example of this trend. She was a devoted scientist who won the Nobel Prize for her work on the structure of penicillin, vitamin B12, and insulin. She also had a personal life, with three children and a husband who was often away on business. Her ability to balance her work and personal life is an inspiration to many.

The challenge for scientific biographers is to communicate the passion and excitement of scientific inquiry to a wider audience. This requires explaining complex scientific concepts in a way that is accessible to non-experts. While it's true that understanding science requires effort and dedication, it's no more difficult than learning a foreign language or reading a novel. It's sad that many educated people remain ignorant of the achievements of scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin, who have made significant contributions to our understanding of the world.<|eot_id|>

Here is the simplified text for a learner of level C1:

Margaret Wilkins is known for her ability to locate water using a forked hazel rod. She has a high success rate, with a success rate of over 90%. Together with her husband, she runs a well-drilling business, using modern technology such as drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers. However, when it comes to locating water, she relies on her'sixth sense'. This ability is also known as dowsing, which involves sensing vibrations in the Earth's surface.

There are various theories about how dowsing works, ranging from physical explanations such as magnetism to spiritual explanations. One theory suggests that everything on Earth vibrates, with water vibrating more than other matter. Dowsers claim that they can sense these vibrations, which helps them locate water.

Margaret's customers are mostly farmers whose wells have dried up, as well as people who own remote cottages or barns that are now holiday homes. She typically locates water between 50 and 70 meters underground. She uses a pendulum to identify likely areas and then walks over the fields with a forked hazel stick to pinpoint the exact spot to drill.

Margaret's method is based on her intuition and experience. She claims that when she is above water, she gets a peculiar feeling and her stick rises up when it is suspended over the water. Her husband also dowses the area, and they usually agree on the exact spot to drill. If they disagree, they won't drill and will continue searching until they agree.

Margaret's ability is not unique, and many anthropologists and writers have studied this phenomenon. They have described it as an 'intuitive perception of the environment', which is the closest explanation to understanding how she locates water so accurately.

Note: I have maintained the factual content of the original text and only simplified the language to make it more accessible to a level C1 learner.<|eot_id|>

"We Swapped Lives for a Day! 

Four people swapped lives for a day to experience something new. Amanda, a young mother of two, switched with her friend Cindy, a waitress at a popular London restaurant. Amanda was surprised by the busy atmosphere and had to learn how to carry trays of drinks. She found it tiring and was relieved to go back to her own life.

Cindy, on the other hand, became a mother for a day. She was responsible for taking care of two young children, making sure they were dressed, fed, and doing their homework. She was exhausted by the end of the day and realized how much work it is to take care of children.

Rosemary, a dairy farmer, swapped with Hilary, a primary school teacher. Rosemary found the school environment overwhelming, with 400 students in one assembly. She was surprised by the amount of work teachers have to do, from preparing lessons to supervising sports activities.

Hilary, the teacher, spent the day on a dairy farm, helping with tasks such as bottling milk, feeding calves, and milking cows. She was surprised by the amount of work involved and the irregular income farmers receive. She also missed the interaction with children and found the work lonely.

All four people learned a lot about each other's jobs and appreciated the challenges and rewards that come with each profession."

**The Careers of Five Women**

Five women share their experiences in different professions. We meet Anne, a brain surgeon; Marita, a senior designer; Linda, a chauffeur; Tracy, a landscape gardener; and Zena, a civil engineer.

**Anne, Brain Surgeon**

Anne wakes up at 6:30 am, goes to the gym, and starts her workday at 8:30 am. She operates on patients and meets with them to explain the procedures. She can work for 10 hours straight without breaks. Although her job can be stressful, she finds it rewarding when patients recover well.

**Marita, Senior Designer**

Marita starts her day at 9:15 am, after a 45-minute commute. She works in a team to design and produce projects. Her day is unpredictable, with multiple tasks and tight deadlines. She enjoys communicating with clients and seeing her designs come to life.

**Linda, Chauffeur**

Linda wakes up at 7 am and works long hours, sometimes up to 15 hours a day. She drives clients to various destinations, often meeting new people and dealing with different personalities. She has to be careful to manage her time and energy levels.

**Tracy, Landscape Gardener**

Tracy starts her day at 7:30 am, maintaining gardens she designed and landscaped. She spends most of her day outdoors, working with her assistant. She loves seeing her designs come to life and enjoys the physical aspect of her job.

**Zena, Civil Engineer**

Zena arrives at the construction site at 8:30 am, overseeing the building of bridges and a retaining wall. She ensures that the contractors follow safety guidelines and specifications. Her day is unpredictable, with unexpected issues to resolve. She works closely with the contractors and other site professionals.

I also do the accounts and tax returns. My day typically ends at 5:30 pm, and it takes me about an hour to wind down.

**D. Air Traffic Controller**

As an air traffic controller, I work a set shift pattern, starting at 7:00 am. I control aircraft movements, working in a team with other controllers, supervisors, and the watch manager. My shift can be stressful, and it takes me a while to wind down after work.

**E. Shop Manager**

As a shop manager, I start my day by setting up the electronic point-of-sale system. I spend the morning helping customers, ordering books, and coordinating staff breaks. In the afternoons, I meet with publishers' reps to discuss new titles and order stock. My shift typically ends at 5:45 pm, and I close down the shop and go home.

**F. Financial Analyst**

As a financial analyst, I start my day by listening to the news and then meeting with freelance reporters to gather information. I assess financial risk for multinational companies and provide three services: an executive preview, security forecast, and travel information security guide. My day is filled with writing and editing, and I often travel to Africa to gather information. I leave work around 6:00 pm and find it difficult to switch off in the evenings.

Here is the simplified text, suitable for a learner of level C1:

**Career Power: Unlock Your Leadership Potential**

What makes a good leader? A leader is someone who inspires, motivates, and shows the way forward. It's not about being tall or intelligent, but about having the ability to make things happen through others who share your enthusiasm and passion.

According to Pat Dixon, a leadership expert, a good leader should be able to communicate clearly and confidently, conveying their ideas and encouraging others to do the same. John van Maurik, a leadership trainer, believes that everyone has the potential to be a leader, but it's about recognizing and developing those talents.

Think about the best and worst bosses you've had. The best leader motivated you and gave you support, while the worst made you feel like just another cog in the machine. Leaders create their own horizons, while managers work within set boundaries.

Whether you're a boss or a middle manager, improving your leadership skills can benefit you. Here are some key lessons to learn:

* Lead from your passions and convictions.
* Recognize your leadership abilities and take charge when needed.
* Experiment with different leadership styles, such as being a negotiator or a motivator.
* Set goals and work towards achieving them.
* Learn to delegate, motivate, and communicate effectively.
* Be visible and accessible to your team, but also know when to step back and let others take the lead.

Remember, leadership is not just about giving orders, but about inspiring and motivating others to achieve their goals. By developing your leadership skills, you can unlock your full potential and achieve greater success in your career.

'Film Reviews by Nick James

A. Abyss - A 1989 thriller about a nuclear submarine stranded deep underwater. The film features impressive production design and special effects, but the dialogue and character development are not as strong. The story is reminiscent of classic B-movies.

B. The Thin Red Line - A 1964 war film based on the novel by James Jones. The director, Andrew Marton, focused on a single soldier and his relationship with his sergeant, creating a more conventional war movie. The film has its moments, including a powerful flashback sequence. In comparison, Terrence Malick's 1998 film is more complex and poetic.

C. On Guard - A swashbuckling adventure loosely based on a 1875 novel. The film features a memorable villain and enjoyable performances from the leads. The film-makers use costume-drama clichés with wit and sparkle, making it an entertaining watch.

D. Character - A period drama set in 19th-century Rotterdam. The film's detailed production and costume design are impressive, but the story is overly focused on period detail. The protagonist's relationship with his son is at the core of the story, but the film fails to explore the dark and vicious themes.

E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly - A classic Western film by Sergio Leone. The digitally remastered video release showcases the director's craftsmanship, particularly in the sound editing. The storytelling is brutal, and the music is magnificent. The moral themes are complex, with the three main characters being equally unscrupulous.

F. The Longest Day - A 1962 war epic directed by four directors and featuring 23,000 extras. The film is an impressive feat, but it feels over-ambitious and would be better suited to the big screen. The early sequences drag, and the film's scope is diminished when viewed on video.'

Here is the simplified text, suitable for a learner of level C1:

At 34, Tim Pozzi has left his job to go backpacking. He's wondering what has made him and others of his age take the plunge. This summer, I quit my job and decided to rent out my flat and travel in South East Asia for a year. You might think I'm lucky, but I'm nervous. I've done some traveling before, but this time it's different. I've been feeling like I've been sacrificing my own happiness for my career.

I've got no ties, and many of my friends are now married with children. They wouldn't swap places with me, but they envy my freedom. I'm no longer in a relationship and I have no burning career ambitions. I feel like I should make the most of this freedom - for my friends' sake, if not for my own.

I'm nervous about making the necessary arrangements, like finding someone to live in my flat and organizing the letting. I'm also worried about deciding where to go. I'm a procrastinator, and I'm already behind schedule. I've told myself to enjoy the summer in England and then think about going away.

I'm also worried about severing emotional ties. I'm putting it off because I wonder if I can still cope with backpacking. Will I be able to adjust to a simpler way of life? Will I feel out of place among backpackers who are fresh out of school and university?

I've discovered that many Britons in their late twenties and thirties are leaving their comfortable lives behind to travel. Jennifer Cox, from Lonely Planet, says that people are realising that adventure is available to them whenever they want it. They just need to be brave enough and organised enough to take the chance.

Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, are going on a round-the-world trip for a year. They're prepared to sacrifice job security for the experience. Matt, who left the Army, spent a year traveling and found it was a period of transformation.

There are many reasons why people travel at this stage of their lives, but there are common factors. Many people have more flexible work arrangements, and some companies even offer career-break policies. For Dan Hiscocks, managing director of Travellerseye, an increasing number of thirty-somethings are taking stock of their lives. He says that people are no longer content with just seeing out their careers and are looking for a more balanced life.

Is giving in to wanderlust a sign of our generation's inability to come to terms with adulthood? Jennifer Cox doesn't think so. She says it's a sign of a better-educated, more stable society that people are taking the time to ask "Is this what I want?"

Ben, a 32-year-old picture researcher, is heading to Central America for a year and doesn't believe he's running away. He's running towards something - trying to grab some things he wants for himself. But he does feel some trepidation. He's worried about leaving behind his comfortable routine and the security of his job.

I share Ben's reservations about leaving behind a comfortable life with few challenges. I'm not sure I'd be making this journey if I hadn't found my boss so intolerable. As Jennifer Cox points out, there's often a catalyst, like a break-up or the loss of a job, that pushes people to take the leap.

I'm approaching the next 12 months with a growing sense of excitement. Whatever the outcome, I'll be able to take satisfaction in having taken control of my life. And I'm sure I speak for all of us aging backpackers.<|eot_id|>

The museum's design is notable for its use of natural light and its varied spaces. The Discovery Centre, designed with input from a group of children, offers a hands-on experience for young visitors. The Twentieth Century gallery, located on the top floor, is a temporary exhibition that will change every three years. It features objects chosen by Scottish people and other personalities as the most significant of the 20th century.

Overall, the National Museum of Scotland is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in Scotland's history and culture. While some may question the modern building's design, the museum's contents and layout are sure to impress.<|eot_id|>

"The end of print newspapers may take some time. Change can be frightening for some and challenging for others. However, transition means moving smoothly from one stage to another. In the case of newspapers, the transition to the online world is uncertain and uncomfortable because it may not be a gradual process. Nevertheless, it is likely to happen eventually. Newspaper sales are declining, while website visits are increasing. This trend is evident in the latest circulation figures. The Daily Telegraph, The Guardian, and many other newspapers have seen a decline in sales of around 8-10% year-on-year, while their websites have seen a significant increase. However, this may not be the whole story. Some experts argue that the crisis mainly affects newspapers, while others claim that magazines and books are thriving. In fact, the latest survey by the World Association of Newspapers shows that global newspaper circulation increased by 1.1% last year, with Asia making up for the decline in the West. News and current affairs magazines even reported a 5.4% increase. When it comes to books, sales have been booming, with e-readers like Kindle experiencing massive growth. However, bookstores have found that the value of physical books they sold over the last six months was only 0.4% lower. This suggests that people are not abandoning print books entirely. The idea that young people are giving up on newspapers is also exaggerated. According to the latest National Readership Survey, nearly 5 million people aged 15-35 follow the main national dailies. In fact, different countries have different stories to tell. For example, while newspaper sales have dropped by 10.8% in Britain, they have only declined by 7% in Germany and 3.1% in France. These varying trends may indicate that the situation is more complex than the digital revolution assumes. In the US, media analysts initially believed that booming online advertising revenues would pay for the transition and make online newspapers successful. However, this assumption has been proven wrong, as digital advertising on newspaper sites is actually declining. As a result, many US newspapers have built paywalls around their products. Interestingly, the best way to attract a paying readership is by offering a joint package of print and digital access. Print is also crucial in selling internet subscriptions, as its advertising rates are significantly higher than online rates. However, maintaining both a print and online presence is complex, expensive, and challenging for newspaper companies. Nevertheless, newspaper brands still have a strong presence in print, which makes it harder to be noticed online."

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of level C1:

**Photographing People: Tips and Techniques**

People are the most interesting subjects to photograph. A picture with someone in it is often more engaging than one without. However, photographing people can be challenging because you need to consider not only technical and artistic aspects but also the subject's actions, gestures, and expressions. The camera's presence can also affect the subject's behavior.

**Group Shots**

* Avoid straight lines in group shots. Ask people to stand at different angles and distances, or have some sit or kneel at the front.
* Make sure everyone's face is visible.

**Posing for Pictures**

* People often stiffen up in front of the camera. Help your subject relax by suggesting a comfortable position, such as folding their arms or putting them in their pockets.

**The Right Approach**

* Be honest and direct when taking a picture. Don't pretend you're not taking a picture, as this can create tension.
* Most people will agree to have their picture taken, and they may even be flattered.

**Eye Contact**

* Ask your subject to look directly into the camera lens. This will create a strong impression. You can remind them just before taking the shot.

**Candid Concentration**

* An alternative to direct eye contact is for the subject to focus on something within the picture area. This can create a natural, unposed look.

**Expressions and Gestures**

* Facial expressions and body language can convey more information about the subject than anything else. Look for natural, authentic expressions.

**Situational Interest**

* A well-chosen background can add interest and context to a picture. Use a wide-angle lens to make the subject stand out.

**Interaction**

* Pictures of people interacting with each other can be powerful. Look for eye contact, physical contact, or reactions to each other.

**People and Places**

* When taking pictures of people in a location, use a standard or wide-angle lens and move back to capture the scene. Ask your subjects to come close to the camera and compose the shot so that both the people and the location are in focus.

**To Pose or Not to Pose?**

* Decide why you're taking the picture. If it's for a memory, a posed shot might be suitable. For candid shots, aim for natural, unposed moments.

'Emotional Intelligence: The Key to Success

In today's workplace, success is not just about being clever or having the right qualifications. Employers are now looking for people who can work well with others and handle themselves effectively. This is known as emotional intelligence. It's the ability to understand and manage your own emotions and those of others.

Emotional intelligence is no longer just a nice-to-have skill, but a must-have for anyone who wants to succeed in their career. It's not just about being nice or being able to express your feelings freely. It's about being able to manage your emotions in a way that helps you achieve your goals.

Companies are now recognizing the importance of emotional intelligence in the workplace. It's especially important in jobs that involve teamwork and customer service. Without emotional intelligence, even the most skilled and knowledgeable person can struggle to succeed.

The good news is that emotional intelligence can be developed and improved over time. With experience and practice, people can become more self-aware, motivated, and skilled at working with others. This is what we call emotional maturity.

Emotional intelligence is not a magic formula for success, but it's a vital ingredient for any organization that wants to thrive. It's not just about being smart or having the right qualifications, but about being able to work effectively with others.'

Here is the simplified text for a learner of level C1:

Ancient Chinese medicine has been used in the West for over 2,000 years. It is based on a traditional system of medicine that includes herbalism, massage, diet, manipulation, and exercise. Acupuncture is used to treat many conditions, but its role in treating pain has received the most attention from Western doctors. Some GPs, midwives, and physios use it regularly for pain relief.

Traditional Chinese medicine sees health as a state where the mind, body, and spirit are in harmony. According to this theory, energy or Qi flows around the body along lines called meridians. When the flow of Qi is disrupted, the body becomes imbalanced, leading to weakness or illness. During a consultation, an acupuncturist will try to find where imbalances occur in the Qi. This is done by feeling pulses on the wrist, examining the tongue, and assessing the patient's general appearance.

The acupuncturist will also ask about the patient's medical history, current health, general well-being, state of mind, and eating and sleeping habits. They use fine needles inserted into the skin to stimulate the flow of Qi. They may also apply warmth from smouldering herbs or pressure at points on meridians.

There are over 300 points on the main meridians, with hundreds more used less frequently. People often report a dull ache or tingling sensation when the needle is manipulated, which is believed to indicate that the needle has reached the Qi in a meridian.

Western doctors have accepted that acupuncture can work for pain relief, even though they do not accept the principles of traditional Chinese medicine. They have provided scientific explanations for how it might work, such as stimulating nerves to block pain signals or releasing natural pain-relieving substances.

Acupuncture is used to treat many types of pain, including chronic long-term pain, back pain, arthritis, headaches, and post-operative pain. Some acupuncturists also claim to treat menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain suffered by terminally ill people.

Although acupuncture has been used in China for over 2,000 years, the use of acupuncture instead of anesthesia during surgery only started in the 1950s. This has helped convince some doctors outside of China that there is more to acupuncture than just mind over matter. In China, acupuncture is used during various operations, including tonsillectomies, caesareans, and open heart surgery.

Acupuncture anesthesia has no side effects and patients recover quickly. However, clinical trials to evaluate acupuncture are difficult to run, and trials that have been done have shown that 50-80% of people find acupuncture effective for chronic pain. Acupuncturists generally quote a similar success rate.

Acupuncturists view pain differently than Western medicine. They consider the patient's overall well-being, not just the symptoms. They spend a long time making a diagnosis, trying to find underlying weaknesses in the Qi. They also consider external factors that may be causing the pain, such as weather or lifestyle.

Some medical professionals have traditional acupuncture training, while others reject traditional Chinese theory and subscribe to scientific explanations. Traditional acupuncturists believe that only by applying traditional Chinese medicine can they bring about deep changes that lead to a longer cure. It is important to choose an acupuncturist who refers patients to a medical doctor if necessary.

James has had a difficult life, even tragic at times. Her husband, a doctor, returned from World War II with serious health problems. James's interest in writing crime novels was not sparked by a fascination with death, but by the challenge of writing a good story within the constraints of the genre. The study of handwriting, known as graphology, is gaining recognition as a tool for understanding a person's character. In some countries, employers ask for handwriting samples when hiring, and it can be a deciding factor in the selection process. Graphology is considered a legitimate science in many countries, and researchers believe it can be used to identify certain health issues, such as heart disease and cancer, as well as psychological states and emotional disturbances.

Graphologists, like Patricia Marne, argue that handwriting can reveal a person's personality, intelligence, and potential. She claims that handwriting can indicate social class, mental ability, and even criminal tendencies. According to Marne, graphology can help identify potential criminals by analyzing their handwriting, which often shows signs of arrested emotional development.

Marne also believes that handwriting can predict future events, such as violence or suicide attempts. She suggests that changes in handwriting over time can indicate serious health problems or emotional upsets. Additionally, she claims that handwriting can reveal other psychological characteristics, such as deviousness, sensitivity, and confidence.

However, some doctors and psychiatrists remain skeptical about the validity of graphology. They argue that handwriting is influenced by education, artistic ability, and writing style, and that it has no scientific basis.

Here is the simplified text for a level C1 learner:

Chewing Gum Culture: A Global Phenomenon

Chewing gum is a popular habit worldwide, with Americans alone consuming 12 million sticks daily. But how did this ancient practice become a multi-billion-dollar industry? Let's explore the fascinating story of chewing gum.

The ancient Greeks chewed a resin obtained from the mastic tree, while American colonists followed the example of Native Americans and chewed the resin that formed on spruce trees. In the late 1800s, the first commercial chewing gum was sold in the United States. However, it wasn't until the discovery of chicle, a milky sap from the sapodilla tree, that modern chewing gum was born.

Chicle, which is still used today, is harvested by chicleros, who trek through the Central American rainforest to collect the sap. This labor-intensive process is fraught with dangers, including poisonous snakes, insects, and the pesky chicle fly that lays eggs in the tappers' ears and nose.

Despite these challenges, the chicleros continue to tap the sapodilla trees, as the demand for chicle is still high. However, with the rise of synthetic alternatives, the demand for natural chicle has decreased significantly. Today, most chewing gum is made from synthetic materials, which are cheaper and easier to produce.

The chewing gum industry has also become increasingly innovative, with manufacturers developing new textures, flavors, and marketing strategies. Some claim that chewing gum can even help reduce tooth decay by increasing salivary flow. Research continues to explore new ways to improve gum products, including the use of glycerine and vegetable oil products.

Interestingly, the United States is home to over 130,000 square kilometers of land dedicated to growing the mint used in the world's most popular chewing gums.

Greaves was concerned about the inspector's criticism, but she reassured him that it was all for the good of the hotel in the long run. Here is the simplified text, adapted for a level C1 reader:

**Conquering the Seven Summits**

As a mountaineer, I have had the privilege of climbing the highest peak on each continent. This is my story of how I achieved this feat.

**A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)**

On my climb to the summit, I found myself talking to my feet due to oxygen deprivation. I was worried about the quality of our survival, not just the act of surviving. I realized I had to get a better rhythm going to reach the summit.

**B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)**

This mountain is known for being the most treacherous in the world. We climbed 'alpine style', carrying our equipment and food on our backs. The air pressure in the polar regions affected our bodies, making it feel like we were climbing at a much higher altitude.

**C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)**

We got lost in the dense jungle on our approach to the mountain. Finding a rock pool and luminous arrows on the trees led us to a safer route. We attempted a direct start but retreated due to falling rock and ice. We opted for the Umbwe route instead.

**D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)**

We joined a guided group to climb the Polish Glacier, but due to bad weather, we decided to take a different route. We walked across the north ridges and joined the standard route. The wind was strong as we reached the summit.

**E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)**

Climbing Vinson Massif was a financial challenge, but it allowed me to attempt all the Seven Summits. We traveled to the South Pole and climbed to the summit in 8 hours despite strong winds and low temperatures.

**F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)**

Our team assembled in St Petersburg and climbed Elbrus via cableway. We acclimatized for a few days before reaching the summit. However, we found that there was another ridge to climb before reaching the actual summit.

**G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)**

We aimed to establish a new route and spend time with the local Dani people. We climbed the mountain, despite warnings of potential danger, and reached the summit by 11 am.

Mission accomplished!<|eot_id|>

We had been living in our valley for 16 months when we realized the dangers that existed in the surrounding hills. It was an unusual year, with storms arriving early, even before November. Until then, we felt safe and sheltered in our valley, protected by the hills. Suddenly, snow started falling, covering our lane and making the streamside path slippery and dangerous. On the higher hills, the snow was much deeper and lasted longer. The wind was strong, but we only felt occasional gusts in our valley. However, we knew we had reason to worry. The snow and wind were inconvenient, but it was the river, the Ryburn, that posed the greatest threat. Normally, it flowed gently, but we remembered that if the dams hadn't been built, the river could have been much more destructive. As the snow started to melt, we watched the clouds gather over the hills, warning us of what was to come. The river began to swell, and we knew it was filling up the reservoir. When the reservoir overflowed for the first time in years, the river became wild and furious, pouring into the stream below. The stream was deeper than we'd ever seen it near our home, lashing against the banks. We prayed for three days that it would stay below its wall, and fortunately, the dam held, and the waters subsided. Before the dam was built, the river had flooded nearby villages many times. Now, the dam restricts the flow, and we can enjoy the power of the river without fear. Thanks to the dam, we feel safe and secure in our valley.

Looking back on the past ten years as a film critic for The Front Page, I remember how it all began. Before joining The Front Page, I had done some freelance reviewing for various newspapers, magazines, and radio stations. That's where I met Tom Seaton, the arts editor, who had also worked in radio and television. He hired me, but Tom wasn't a traditional journalist, so he made some unconventional decisions. His idea was to have a team of critics covering various art forms, including books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. We would meet weekly to discuss our assignments and socialize over lunch. It was a dream come true to be part of a new newspaper, and I felt a mix of excitement and skepticism. However, the team never quite gelled, and we ended up working independently by phone. The public preferred to associate critics with a specific area of expertise, so I focused on film. Without Tom's initial guidance, I wouldn't have developed my current style of writing extended reviews on a single film each week. I prefer this approach, as it allows me to explore complex ideas and make the most of my time. As for my role in the public sphere, I don't think film reviews are meant to be a definitive guide for what to watch. Instead, I aim to present a thoughtful argument about the film. I don't feel responsible for being 'right' or for categorizing films as 'great' or 'bad'. My job is simply to offer my perspective.

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500 meters, cycle 40 kilometers, and then run 10 kilometers? Because it's fun! A teenager with a passion for endurance is looking for a training partner, preferably a female, to work with a potential Olympic champion. The ideal candidate should be extremely keen on distance running (regular 15-kilometer sessions), distance swimming (a love for winter training in cold rivers is a plus), and distance cycling (a love of 10-kilometer rides is an advantage). The ability to do all three without a break is essential.

The triathlon is one of the most popular Olympic sports. Recently, it has attracted huge crowds who are both fascinated and horrified by athletes swimming 1500 meters, cycling 40 kilometers, and then running 10 kilometers without stopping. What motivates these athletes to push their bodies to such extremes? And what drives a 17-year-old with excellent academic results to give up everything for the uncertain rewards of triathlon?

Melanie Sears, a 17-year-old triathlete, has not yet learned the usual phrases about personal satisfaction, mental challenge, and higher targets that many athletes use when asked similar questions. "You swim 1500 meters, then run out of the water and jump on your bike, still wet. Of course, then you freeze. After the 40-kilometer cycle ride, you have to run 10 kilometers, which is a long way when you're exhausted. But it's great fun, and it's all worth it in the end," she says.

Melanie started competing in triathlons at 14. She won the junior section, but then she was the only junior taking part. She felt so confident that she entered the National Championships, but she didn't do as well as she expected. "I was following this man, and suddenly we came to the sea. We realized then that we had gone the wrong way. I ended up cycling 20 kilometers too far. I cried all the way through the run." But she didn't give up and is determined not to.

Melanie's dogged determination has earned her admiration from Steve Trew, the sport's director of coaching. "I've been testing her fitness, and she worked so hard on the running machine that it finally threw her off and into a wall. She had given it everything, but whereas most people step off when they realize they can't go any further, she just kept going." Melanie was the top junior in this year's European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. "I was almost as good as the top three in swimming and running, but much slower at cycling. That's why I'm working hard at it."

Melanie is trying to convince her parents to buy her a new bike, which will cost £2,000, so she can compete in national 25-kilometer and 100-kilometer races later this year. However, there is another price to pay. Her demanding training sessions have made her a bit of a recluse. "I don't have a social life," she says. "I'm not a party animal anyway. After two hours of hard swimming on Friday nights, I just want to sleep. But I phone and write to the other girls in the team." What do they talk about? Boys? Clothes? "No, what times they're achieving." Where will all this single-mindedness take her? Melanie has tried other events, such as the triathlon "sprint," where you only have to swim 750 meters, cycle 20 kilometers, and run 5 kilometers. She wants to enter even tougher events than the triathlon. "The big trouble is, I have no one of my age to train with," she says. Strange, that.<|eot_id|>

Here is the rewritten text at a level suitable for a learner of English at C1:

The world of collecting is a fascinating one, with one in three adults indulging in this hobby. As someone who has always loved collecting, I can attest to the thrill of the hunt and the joy of acquiring new items. But it's essential to remember that, ultimately, if you don't fall in love with an object, you shouldn't collect it.

Throughout history, humans have been drawn to collecting. From ancient times, people have gathered objects for intellectual and spiritual reasons. Children still collect stones, seashells, and other natural treasures for their beauty and uniqueness. I've been collecting my entire life, with my first collection being a set of stones from my parents' garden. As I grew older, my interests expanded to include flowers, pottery, and paintings.

My love for collecting was sparked by visits to a local museum in a remote part of England, where I would marvel at the objects on display. It's not just me, though – many people share this passion. In fact, one in three adults collects something. The reasons behind this phenomenon are complex, with some individuals seeking control and others simply enjoying the thrill of the hunt.

Throughout history, famous collectors have made their mark. The Duc de Berry in France amassed a 'room of wonders,' featuring natural and artificial curiosities. Catherine the Great of Russia, meanwhile, collected over 4,000 paintings. However, you don't need to be wealthy or powerful to start a collection. I've collected everything from tulip bulbs to china cups, driven by a sense of determination and curiosity.

One of my most memorable collections was of American rag dolls – I found 350 of them across the United States. Unfortunately, a fire destroyed the collection, leaving me with a sense of loss. The way collections change hands and the stories behind the objects are what truly fascinate me. A silver spoon once owned by a king or a poet can give an object immense value, making it a valuable commodity in the world's markets. As items become popular, their value increases, making them a shrewd investment – as long as you keep the original packaging, that is.<|eot_id|>

Sarah has a busy Sunday, as she has to prepare breakfast for the guests who are leaving at 7 a.m. After they've gone, she spends the morning cleaning and doing the week's shopping. She then prepares tea for the new guests, who arrive at 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they're disoriented and have lots of questions. Sarah takes them to the ski shop to get their equipment and then heads back to the chalet.

After tea, Sarah takes some guests to the ski shop and then has dinner duty again. She might have a drink later, but sometimes she's too tired and just goes to bed early.

In the lumberyard by the lake, there was an old brick building with a roof where the workers would often gather. The yard was covered in soft sawdust, which was piled high all around the building. One afternoon, the workers decided to climb up to the roof and sit down, looking out at the lake. Michael, who was always looking for a thrill, dared the others to jump off the roof. At first, they were hesitant, but eventually they all took the leap and laughed as they rolled around in the sawdust.

Encouraged by the others, Michael went up to the roof again and dared them to jump again. But this time, he was the only one who didn't jump. He stood at the edge of the roof, looking down at the others, who were grinning up at him. Michael wanted to join them, but he was too scared. He tried to count to ten and then jump, but he couldn't do it. He tried to take a deep breath and close his eyes, but he still couldn't bring himself to jump.

The others started to get impatient and began to leave, calling out to Michael to come down. But he remained on the roof, staring at the ground. He stayed there for nearly an hour, feeling embarrassed and ashamed. As the sun began to set, he finally closed his eyes and jumped off the roof, landing heavily in the sawdust. He lay there for a long time, feeling miserable. When he finally got up and went home, his stepmother was angry with him for being late. She told him he was old enough to get home on time and that he should stay in for dinner. Michael was too ashamed to look at her and went to his room, still thinking about the way the others had laughed at him.

Jerome says that many people only visit the dentist when they're in pain, because they're afraid. To make them feel more at ease, he has created a relaxed atmosphere. He doesn't wear a white coat, which people often associate with pain. Instead, he aims to create a sense of relaxation, interest, and enjoyment during dental treatment. This is a big change from the traditional, clinical experience many people are used to.

To help patients relax, Jerome uses virtual-reality headsets. He was the first dentist in Britain to introduce them, and they're very popular. During the initial check-up, patients wear the headset and watch a film about underwater wildlife while Jerome examines their teeth. Then, the headset shows them a virtual tour of their mouth. Many patients enjoy this part of their visit.

The surgery also has a pleasant, non-dentist-like smell, such as orange today. Jerome believes that people's senses, including their sense of smell, play an important role in creating a relaxing atmosphere. He is known as Glasgow's most fashionable dentist, but he takes his work very seriously. The relaxation techniques are important, but the quality of the treatment is the most important thing. For example, he uses a special instrument that sprays warm water on the teeth to clean them, rather than scraping them. This may feel strange at first, but it's not painful if patients are relaxed.

Jerome has also learned from his research in the United States that making it easier for patients makes it easier for dentists too. He believes that his patient-centred approach is the start of a trend towards less formality in British dentistry. As I watched, a patient arrived, and Jerome offered him a cup of tea, asked what video he'd like to watch, and led him to the chair. The patient seemed to be enjoying the five-star treatment, and it's no wonder. The surgery feels more like an elegant beauty parlour than a traditional dental practice.'

Chocolate has a long history that dates back over 3,000 years to the time of the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilisations in Central America. They cultivated the cacao tree, an evergreen plant found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and South-East Asia. The fruit of the tree contains 20-40 seeds, which are dried to become cacao beans. These beans are used to make chocolate, and in English-speaking countries, they are often referred to as cocoa beans. In the past, cacao beans were used as a form of currency and to make a drink called xocoatl, which was flavoured with spices and used on special occasions.

The Spanish discovered the drink and mixed it with cinnamon and sugar, but it didn't become popular in Europe until the 17th century. Chocolate houses were set up in European cities, where people would gather to drink the beverage. In the 19th century, the process of making chocolate changed with the invention of chocolate powder and the chocolate bar. Today, the UK is one of the biggest consumers of chocolate, spending over £230 million on it at Easter alone. However, the chocolate industry has had to adapt to changing consumer habits, with manufacturers introducing new products such as chocolate-flavoured ice cream and soft drinks.

The production of chocolate also has its challenges, with cacao farmers still feeling the effects of a crash in cocoa bean prices in the late 1980s. Many small-scale farmers were forced out of business, and it's worth remembering their struggles as we enjoy our chocolate treats.

As he shows me his work, he asks if I'm getting bored. But his enthusiasm is infectious, and his creations are truly stunning. Cooke wishes he had started earlier, as he would have been able to produce even more amazing pieces. However, he's still creating beautiful work, using his own unique method and materials. He insists that he only collects dead shells and defends himself against people who accuse him of stripping the world's beaches. The local community is cautiously optimistic about the prospect of gold being found, as it could bring in more tourists. However, some are concerned about the potential impact on the environment.

The Welsh gold industry has declined significantly since its peak in the late 1880s, when there were hundreds of mines in the area. However, individual prospectors are still searching for gold, and one, George Hall, plans to dig a tunnel on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens. For him, searching for gold is an exciting and emotional adventure, and he hopes to strike it lucky this time.

Here is the simplified text for a C1 level learner:

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends as much time as possible at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University and teaches marine geochemistry, which involves studying the chemical processes in the sea. When she's not teaching, she dives down to the ocean floor in a special vehicle, called a submersible, to study underwater volcanoes. The submersible is about the size of a small car and can take her down to a depth of three kilometers.

Inside the submersible, space is very limited, and Rachel can reach out and touch the two pilots who accompany her on the dive. They are used to these conditions and know they can't stand up or move around. The dive can last up to 16 hours, including three hours to reach the ocean floor, 10 hours to collect samples, and three hours to return to the surface.

If anything goes wrong, Rachel can hit a panic button, which releases a small escape vessel that rapidly rises to the surface. Rachel has made six dives, including one with a Russian crew to a site west of the Canary Islands. There, they found a huge area of underwater volcanoes, with chimneys spewing out black smoke.

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre. Two-thirds of her salary comes from teaching, which she enjoys, but she does it so she can focus on her research into underwater volcanoes. She has been studying them for three years and has even written her PhD thesis on the subject.

Rachel has had a few scary moments during her dives, including one when an explosion occurred while she was towing equipment on a 50-meter rope. But she has also experienced incredible relief and a sense of wonder when she sees the underwater volcanoes up close. She feels privileged to be one of the few people who have seen these natural wonders.<|eot_id|>

Sleeping on train corridors and carrying all my belongings in a backpack made me appreciate the basics of travel and encouraged a carefree attitude. This was in line with the spirit of Inter-Rail, where you could forget about practicalities and just enjoy the journey. We were amazed by the freedom to travel to multiple countries in a day, and the cost was minimal. On my first trip, my friends and I initially thought the ticket was just a cheap way to get to our campsite in southern France, but we soon discovered the thrill of non-stop travel. We visited many countries, taking in the sights and experiences, and making the most of our independence. We were proud of the fact that we could do things our own way, without a guided tour. We just wanted to have a good time and enjoy the journey. As we travelled, we met other young people doing the same thing, sharing food, music, and stories. The excitement of travel comes from experiencing a place for the first time, seeing the city with your own eyes. It's not just about seeing famous landmarks, but about understanding the culture and way of life. Inter-Rail gives you the opportunity to see Europe in a unique way, to appreciate its diversity and complexity. For us, it was a valuable personal experience, even if we didn't immediately realize its full potential.

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of level C1:

Losing your luggage when traveling can be frustrating. Imagine arriving at an airport and finding out that your suitcase has been left behind. You may have to wear the same clothes for hours or even days until the airline returns your luggage. This can be particularly problematic if you're traveling to a different climate or a long distance from home.

Airlines rarely reveal how many bags they lose, but it's a fact that even frequent travelers will eventually experience this problem. Even the best airlines can make mistakes, and it's impossible to guarantee that your luggage will be on the same flight, especially if you have a layover.

The baggage system works like this: airlines require passengers to check in early to allow time for luggage to be processed and loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times are also set to allow for baggage transfers. However, delays caused by security checks and air traffic control issues can disrupt the system. Human error or accidents can also cause luggage to be lost.

Large transfer airports, also known as hubs, are particularly prone to luggage mishaps. For example, London's Heathrow airport handles over 41 million passengers each year, with many changing planes. Even efficient airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich can have bad days.

If you're changing planes, consider taking a direct flight or flying with the same airline throughout. Try to allow extra time for connections by taking an earlier flight and labeling your luggage clearly with your home and holiday addresses, as well as the flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, report it to the airline official in the baggage hall and complete a property irregularity report before leaving the airport.

"Variations on a Theme: A Review of Theme Parks in Britain

We asked five families to visit different theme parks in Britain and share their experiences. Here's what they thought:

Fun Island - The Burns Family

We visited Fun Island with our three-year-old and were impressed. The park caters well to young children, with rides like the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There's even a special dodgems ride for the very young. Older kids can enjoy scarier rides like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! The staff were helpful, and the park was clean and well-organized.

Wonderland - The McMillan Family

We hadn't been to a theme park before, but our three-year-old loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and Little Land, with its miniatures of famous buildings. The older kids enjoyed the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a real road layout. The landscaping was perfect, and the staff were friendly and helpful.

Adventure World - The Jeffree Family

We spent seven hours at Adventure World and still didn't see everything. The kids loved the Big Top Circus and the Terror Line, which was a bit scary but fun. They also enjoyed Running River, where you think you'll get soaked but don't. The park is well-designed, and even queuing wasn't boring. It was spotless, and the staff were great.

The Great Park - The Langridge Family

We arrived at one o'clock and were disappointed it closed at five. This park is perfect for younger kids, with rides that aren't too scary. We all enjoyed Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts calmly and gets exciting. We queued for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over before we knew it! If the kids were a bit older, they might have found it tame, but they were the right age and loved it.

Fantasy World - The Break-all Family

Fantasy World lived up to its promise of 'No Limit to the Fun'. The Rocket, Europe's tallest rollercoaster, dominates the skyline, and the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was terrifying! There are plenty of main rides for older kids, and Sarah enjoyed the Long Slide. The staff were a bit mixed, but the park was clean and well-organized. We wouldn't have dared leave early!"

Meet the Amazing Watkins Family

The Watkins family is quite unique. Both parents, John and Hetty, are music teachers. Their sons, Paul and Huw, are talented musicians. But what makes them special is that their father, John, also makes musical instruments. When their son Paul, who was 10 years old at the time, needed a cello for his music lessons, they couldn't afford to buy one. So John decided to learn how to make one himself. He took evening classes at the Welsh School of Instrument Making for three years.

John's first cello turned out well, and he made another one for Paul a bit later. Paul used that cello until a few months ago. John has since retired from teaching and now makes violins full-time. He even sold one to a famous American musician, Jaime Laredo, which was a great achievement.

Both Paul and Huw were encouraged to play music from a young age. They started with the piano, but Paul soon discovered his passion for the cello. Huw, on the other hand, took a bit longer to find his instrument, but he eventually became a skilled pianist and composer.

Paul's cello, made by his father, helped him win several music competitions, including the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition. He was also appointed principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra at a young age. However, he has recently acquired a new cello on loan from the Royal Academy of Music.

Huw, who is now 22, is also making a name for himself as a pianist and composer. The Watkins family is proud of their musical achievements, but they also know how to balance their busy schedules and support each other.
