Here is the simplified version of the text for a learner of level C1:

**Specialist Music Schools for Gifted Children**

Parents of children with exceptional musical talent often struggle to find the right way to nurture their child's gift. Many parents may not recognize their child's need until their frustration boils over into bad behavior. While most schools are equipped to handle academically gifted students, music schools require a different approach. Children with exceptional musical ability may benefit from a specialist music school, especially if they are actively encouraged by parents or teachers.

In Britain, there are five specialist music schools that offer a supportive environment for gifted children aged 7-18 to develop their skills under the guidance of professional musicians. These schools provide a unique balance between music and academic education. Students spend about one-third to one-half of their day on musical activities, such as individual lessons, orchestras, and theory. They also have private practice rooms with teachers. The rest of their time is spent on a limited academic program, focusing on essential subjects like English, math, and languages.

The schools are independent and have a high teacher-to-student ratio. Most students are boarders, living at school full-time. This allows them to be surrounded by like-minded peers. However, there are some drawbacks. The fees are high (around £12,000-£17,000 per year for boarders). Some parents may also worry about the cost and the idea of sending their child to boarding school at a young age.

Some experts question whether it is wise to separate musically gifted children from their peers at such a young age. They argue that this can lead to stress and pressure to perform. However, the schools closely monitor individual progress and offer support if needed. While many former students appreciate the high-quality music education, some express concerns about the limited academic program.

For some families, it may be better to wait until the child is old enough to make their own decisions before considering a specialist education. Alternatively, children who are equally gifted academically may thrive in a less specialized environment, such as a school with a strong music department or through part-time music training at a music college. However, this option may not be practical for families living outside of major cities.<|eot_id|>

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of level C1:

Trying to get published? If you're wondering where to send your story, Margaret Stubbs is here to help. Many readers of this magazine ask, 'I've written a story/book, can you tell me who to send it to?' First, you need to research your markets and learn about publishers. You also need to improve your writing skills. To succeed, you need to know the 'writing game' inside out. No matter what kind of writing you do, you need to understand the markets you're targeting. One way to do this is to read widely. Visit your local library and bookshops, and read everything relevant you can find. This will give you a good idea of what kinds of writing publishers are looking for at any given time. As new publications emerge, you need to stay up-to-date with the latest developments.

If you're not sure what you want to write, start by identifying your niche. For example, if you want to write love stories, find out which magazines publish them and read recent issues. Understand what kind of stories they buy and who their readers are. These readers have certain expectations, and editors only want to cater to their needs.

Many writers send me their work, saying, 'This has been rejected three times - am I wasting my time?' As a former teacher, I would never discourage anyone, but it's unlikely that the work is publishable. Most new writers send out their work too early, usually before they're ready. It's rare for a writer to be published with just one story or article. When you do finally send out your work, keep writing while you wait for a response. Write multiple stories, and each one will be better than the last. Don't be discouraged by rejections - every successful writer has faced many rejections before succeeding.

I would advise not sharing your work with others in the early stages. Instead, join a creative writing course or a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence from other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and make writing a daily habit.<|eot_id|>

end_header_id|>
Here is the simplified version of the text, suitable for a learner of English at level C1:

On the last day of a difficult year, I was waiting for my train to Philadelphia at Baltimore station. There were more people waiting than I expected. The usual feeling of calm and order in the station was gone. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and students sprawled on the floor with their bags. A well-dressed man was walking around, talking to strangers. He approached a woman sitting alone and asked her a question. Then he came to a girl standing near me, with long blonde hair. I thought I might have liked to talk to her. The man asked her if she was going to Philadelphia. She said she was going to New York, but would be passing through Philadelphia. He thanked her and moved on to the next bench.

Now I was interested in him. He asked an elderly woman if she was going to Philadelphia, and when she said she was going to Wilmington, he didn't respond and continued to the next bench. I straightened up and walked closer, pretending to look at the platform. I was going to Philadelphia, and he could have asked me. I understood why he didn't - I must have seemed unreliable. He glanced at me quickly and moved on to the other end of the waiting area. He was looking very stressed. 'Please!' he said to a woman reading a book. 'Tell me you're going to Philadelphia!' She put down her book and said she was going to Philadelphia. He asked her for a favour.

I was a few feet away and frowned at my wrist (I don't own a watch). The woman seemed wary, and the man said his daughter was flying out that afternoon and he needed to get her passport from Philadelphia. His wife was upset because their daughter had forgotten her passport, and he was too busy to go himself because his wife was in a wheelchair. The woman was sympathetic, but I thought the story sounded unlikely. Why didn't he go himself? 'Why don't you go yourself?' the woman asked. He was holding a padded envelope, which seemed suspicious. I thought to myself, 'Watch yourself, lady!'

Finding a decent flat in Dublin at a reasonable price was like searching for a needle in a haystack. The best way to find one was through personal connections. If you knew someone who knew someone who was leaving a flat, that often worked. However, if you were like Jo, who had just arrived in Dublin, it was a different story. You didn't have any connections to rely on. You had to stay in a hostel and search for a flat. For Jo, Dublin was a vast unknown territory. She felt like she was taking a huge risk by moving there without knowing what to expect. She didn't even ask herself why she was moving there in the first place. It was just assumed that she would go to Dublin. Who would stay in a small town, the middle of nowhere, when everyone was moving to the city to escape and experience life?

Jo's mother thought it would be great if she stayed in the hostel permanently, as it was run by nuns and she would be safe. Her father worried about the temperature in the hostel, as they were known to be cold. Jo's sisters, who worked in a hotel, thought she was crazy for staying in a hostel for a week. But Jo was determined to find a flat of her own.

Jo saw an advertisement for a flat in Ringsend that seemed too good to be true. It had its own room, TV, and shared kitchen and bathroom. It was close to the post office where she worked. She was nervous as she arrived at the flat, hoping it would be nice and not too expensive. The house looked ordinary, a red-brick terraced house with a basement. Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of level C1:

Dolphins are loved by many people. We enjoy watching them in marine parks, films, and TV shows. However, according to the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, their situation is critical. Mark Simmonds reports on the decline of the species.

Dolphins are highly intelligent animals that can sense human emotions. They have a special place in our hearts, and we often imagine them living freely in the ocean. This affection has been encouraged by TV shows like Flipper and Darwin from Seaquest. However, these positive portrayals hide the harsh reality of dolphins' lives in polluted and overfished seas.

The population of North Sea harbour porpoises has decreased by up to 89,000. You might expect such popular animals to be protected by law and cared for in marine reserves. Unfortunately, this is not the case, and the lack of plans to protect them may become one of the biggest wildlife disasters of our time.

There are 40 different dolphin species worldwide. In northern European waters, the most common are striped, common, bottlenose, and harbour porpoise dolphins. The first two are usually found far out at sea, and we know little about them. The larger grey bottlenoses and harbour porpoises were once common near European coasts. Bottlenoses are social and used to be found on the Channel coast and in British river mouths, including the Thames. However, resident populations are now only found in Scotland and Wales, and the skin injuries on the few remaining individuals indicate that they are suffering from stress.

The complex habits of dolphins make it difficult to determine the exact reasons for their decline. Overfishing, which is drastically reducing global fish stocks and threatening local fishing industries, also threatens porpoises and dolphins. This is because porpoises need to find food within a limited time frame. If fish in one area are removed by fishing, they may not survive long enough to find food elsewhere. They are also in danger of getting caught in fishermen's nets, which are thought to be invisible to them.

In recent years, hundreds of dead dolphins have washed up on French and Cornish beaches. Marks, ropes, and cuts on their bodies show that the main cause of death was being caught in these nets. Dolphins can store waste and other substances in their bodies, such as pesticides, which can build up in their fat. Female dolphins can then pass these poisons to their young through their milk, as seen in one recorded case where a young dolphin was poisoned and killed by its mother's milk.

The most controversial threat to dolphins is human disturbance. Dolphins live in groups and receive information about their environment through sound. Noise pollution from ships, oil wells, and other sources is transmitted four times more efficiently in the sea than in the air, which may disturb dolphins in ways we do not yet understand.

There are various types of exercise to choose from, including aerobics, calisthenics, jogging, weightlifting, and using weight machines. Stretching exercises are also vital for maintaining flexibility, ease of movement, and preventing injuries. Aim to stretch four to five times a week to achieve optimal results. A well-rounded exercise routine should include a warm-up, stretching exercises, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period. By incorporating these elements, you can achieve a fitter, more flexible body and overall improved well-being."

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends most of her time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and conducts research on marine geochemistry, studying the chemical processes that occur in the sea. She is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she's not teaching, Rachel dives down to the ocean floor in a special vehicle, similar to a small car, to study underwater volcanoes. The space inside the vehicle is very limited, so she can't stand up or move around, and they have to stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can take up to 16 hours, including three hours to reach the ocean floor, 10 hours to collect samples, and three hours to return to the surface.

If there's an emergency, Rachel can press a panic button, which releases a small escape vessel that quickly rises to the surface. She's made six dives so far, including one with a Russian team to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands. There, they found a huge area of underwater volcanoes, their chimneys spewing out black smoke.

When she's not at sea, Rachel is in her office at the Oceanography Centre. She loves teaching, which accounts for two-thirds of her salary, but she does it to support her research on underwater volcanoes, also known as "black smokers". These volcanoes are characterized by water flowing out of the rock at a rate of one meter per second and a temperature of 350 degrees.

Rachel has had a few frightening experiences, including an explosion during a dive with an American team. However, she's also experienced moments of wonder and amazement when she sees the underwater volcanoes up close. She's been studying black smokers for three years, and seeing them for the first time was an incredible feeling.

Here is the simplified version of the text, suitable for a learner of English at level C1:

First impressions are crucial. Research shows that people form an opinion about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our body language, tone of voice, and the words we use. Mary Pearce, a teacher, learned this the hard way. She didn't get a job at a nearby school because the Head Teacher was put off by a small hole in her jacket. The teacher's comment was: 'If someone doesn't take the time to present themselves well, what kind of teacher will they be?'

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, agrees: 'When you look professional, it shows you care about your job.' Many people underestimate the importance of a good impression. For example, Janet Goodwood was passed over for a promotion because she didn't fit the image of an office manager. The Director of Personnel suggested she improve her wardrobe before reapplying.

Body language also plays a significant role in making a good impression. According to psychologist Albert Mehrabian, 55% of our message comes from our facial expressions, 38% from our voice, and only 7% from our words. It's essential to ensure that our words and body language match. Mixed messages can confuse the interviewer.

It's also important not to appear too desperate or overly eager for the job. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, learned this the hard way. She was offered a job on the spot, but her enthusiasm led the interviewer to offer her a lower salary than she had hoped for.

Finally, preparation is key. David Artesio, a manager at an employment agency, suggests researching the company before the interview and being prepared to ask informed questions. Marian Woodall, a business consultant, advises using short, clear sentences and having a few prepared questions ready.<|eot_id|>

Here is the simplified version of the text, suitable for a learner of English at level C1:

Shopping with children can be a challenging experience for many parents. They often find themselves torn between giving in to their children's demands and resisting the temptation to buy them everything they want. One mother describes the experience as "absolute murder", saying that her children want everything they see, from the latest sugary cereals to Disney videos and comics. She feels guilty about buying things she knows are not good for them, but also worries that saying no all the time will make her children feel deprived and resentful.

Research has shown that children make a purchase request every two minutes when they are taken shopping with their parents. The advertising industry spends over £150 million a year targeting children, mostly through television ads. This is likely to increase, and supermarkets are the most effective place for these advertisements to be successful.

Children often don't understand why their parents can't afford certain things, and the arguments about the negative effects of sugar on their teeth are often ineffective against the persuasive power of advertising. According to Susan Dibb of the National Food Alliance, parents are concerned about what they feed their children, but their ideas about healthy food are not always accurate. She believes that parents and children should have a dialogue about food, as relying solely on TV advertising can give children a one-sided view.

Despite regulations prohibiting advertisers from telling children to ask their parents to buy products, the intention of advertising is still to persuade the viewer to make a purchase. This can put parents in a difficult position, as they feel they are competing with the advertising industry and are forced to repeatedly disappoint their children.

For some parents, the mental effort required to decide which demands to agree to and which to refuse can be exhausting. One mother says she has learned to manage her son's shopping demands by discussing food and reading labels with him, which has reduced conflict in the supermarket. However, parents often admit to being inconsistent and hypocritical in their responses to their children's requests.

Supermarkets could do more to ease parent-child conflict by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. While parents might spend less if their children were not with them, the thought of shopping without their children's demands would likely attract enough customers to make up for the loss.

Here is the simplified text, suitable for a learner of level C1:

Ice skating has a long history. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones, which were used until iron was introduced in Scandinavia around 200 AD. In Scandinavian society, skating was a valuable skill. In the early 20th century, skating was seen as a fashionable and exclusive activity, but the 1924 Winter Olympics introduced a more athletic approach, popularizing the sport. Today, ice skating combines art and athleticism, requiring both elegance and physical fitness.

For beginners, balance and control are crucial. To maintain balance, it's essential to keep your body centered, with your legs slightly bent and your knees bent. Relaxation is vital, especially when starting out. Keep your heels close together and your feet turned outwards. Move your back foot forward while making a small movement with the other foot.

It's essential to learn how to fall safely. Even experienced skaters fall, but by staying relaxed, the impact is minimized. To get up, kneel and then stand. Once you're comfortable moving on the ice, you can explore different styles, such as figure skating, freestyle, and speed skating. The best way to start is by learning figure skating and then progressing to elementary freestyle.

Most ice rinks offer guidance to help you learn the basics, and with practice, you can master the turns, jumps, and spins. Professional skaters demonstrate relaxation and ease of movement. To achieve this, regular exercise is necessary. A warm-up routine should include exercises for your legs, back, and shoulders, with a focus on your ankles and knees. After a long or intense session, repeat the exercises to prevent stiffness.

Ice skating improves balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also strengthens the heart and lungs and can be combined with swimming or jogging for a comprehensive fitness program.<|eot_id|>

|end_header_id|>

'Trills and Bills: The Joys and Challenges of Being a Young Athlete

Julia Gregson spoke to three talented young athletes and their mothers about the rewards and difficulties of their lives. 

A. Annika Reeder, 15, won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. Her goal is to become a physiotherapist and compete in the Olympics. 'Training is very demanding. I have no time for TV, socializing, or leisure activities. I try to focus on one day at a time, and when I'm exhausted, my coach gives me a break. But usually, I keep going - you can't afford to take too many days off, or you'll lose your edge.'

B. Annika's mother 'Annika showed great potential from a young age. We've seen parents pushing their children too hard, but it doesn't work. To perform at Annika's level requires a huge amount of time and energy. People often say we've sacrificed a lot, but they don't see what the sport has given us. We love it, and it's given Annika confidence and success.'

C. Sarah Stokes started show-jumping at 10 and has since won the British National Championship. 'I'm lucky my parents like show-jumping because they train me and take me to competitions. The shows can last from one to five days. I never get tired of it - I love the excitement and thrill of competition. I'm determined to qualify for the British young riders' team and win an Olympic gold medal.'

D. Sarah's mother 'Sarah has been passionate about horses since she was one. At five, she would get up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for major shows, we have to travel all over England. We even sleep in our horse box to save money. Sarah is very organized and knows exactly what she's doing. It's wonderful to see your child succeed at something they love.'

E. Jane McShane, 10, is the Under-14 Chess Champion. 'Tournaments are really friendly, and I know everyone. When I'm playing, I don't concentrate - I just stare around and don't think. I'm not worried about getting too confident, and I don't talk about my successes at school. I don't like drawing attention to myself.'

F. Jane's mother 'Jane started playing chess at five, and she loved it from the beginning. By the end of that first afternoon, she had memorized all the moves. By six, she was beating adults. Of course, I'm proud when she wins, but if she said she wanted to give up tomorrow, I wouldn't stop her. On the other hand, I wouldn't want to discourage her from pursuing her gift.'

Chris Greener, the tallest man in Britain, is 228 cm tall. This is because the average height of people in Europe is increasing by one centimetre every decade. In fact, we are returning to the height of our ancestors who lived 40,000 years ago. This is because, for most of human history, our ancestors ate a varied diet that included fruits, berries, and animals. However, with the invention of agriculture 9,000 years ago, our diet changed and we started to rely more on carbohydrates like wheat, rice, and maize. This has had a negative impact on our health and physique.

In the past, people who ate a diet rich in carbohydrates were underfed and underdeveloped. A study in Ohio found that when people switched from a hunter-gatherer diet to an agricultural diet, they became sickly and underweight. Tooth decay and diseases increased, and people's overall health declined. It wasn't until recently that people began to realize the importance of a balanced diet.

Today, the average height of people in some countries, like the US, Holland, and Japan, is increasing again due to improved nutrition. However, scientists are unsure about the upper limit of human height. Some believe it could be as much as 193 cm, but others think it may be offset by global warming, which could cause humans to shrink.

Coming from Scotland, I found the landscape familiar yet different. I still go back there today. In my diary, I'd write about my adventures. This was my first attempt at writing about travel, which later became my profession.

I also enjoy taking the miniature train from Hythe to Dungeness. The scenery isn't spectacular, but I love watching everyday life unfold through people's back gardens. I see myself in their eyes, a stranger peeking into their homes. It's the ordinary, unassuming landscape that fascinates me.

I've also visited the Hartland Peninsula, a remote and beautiful coast. The beaches are hard to reach, so there are few tourists. It's a great place for surfers and those who want to appreciate the sea. The coast is known for shipwrecks, and there are many scenic walks you can take inland to explore the valleys and forests.

My friend Annette loves the Trough of Bowland, a vast, open moorland perfect for hiking. It's a quiet, remote area with few residents and visitors. She discovered it by chance and has been returning every year, sometimes with her family.

My friend James has a special place in England, a secluded house called Glenthorne. He bought it to find peace and reconnect with his English roots. He grew up in Sri Lanka but went to school in Devon and loved exploring the countryside. Glenthorne is a magical, romantic place where you can only hear the sound of the sea, wind, and birds.'

WE'RE ANIMAL PEOPLE We love animals and enjoy their company. One afternoon, our chain of events ended in total confusion. My daughter called me at work with exciting news: she had found a beautiful pine snake. 'Can we keep him?' she asked. I agreed, but only for one night. We had a special tank for temporary guests, and I wanted to admire and learn more about the snake. I was running late, so I quickly boiled some water as I rushed home. Suddenly, I heard screams from my sons' bedroom. I rushed in to find Domino, our cat, chasing Bianca, a white mouse, around the room. The cat had caught the mouse and was trying to escape with its prey. I joined the chaos, tripped, and found myself on the floor. As I tried to catch Domino, I saw the snake escaping from the table and spreading across the floor. The scene was chaotic, with the snake hissing, the cat and mouse running around, and the kids screaming. I managed to catch Domino by the tail and rescue the mouse from his jaws. The snake, however, was more elusive. It had no weak points, so I had to use a different approach. I sat on the floor, rocking back and forth, and eventually the snake relaxed enough to let me pick it up. I walked to the end of the garden and released the snake near a tree. To my surprise, it curled up around my shoulders and seemed to enjoy the warmth. We stood there, my children, the snake, and I, in silence. Then my eldest son explained, 'You're warm and comfortable, Mum, and the shed isn't.' I gently encouraged the kids to help the snake move away from the shed. It slowly slid up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last bit of tail disappeared, my three-year-old son sighed and said, 'That was one big snake!'<|eot_id|>

'Write to me! In today's world of emails, text messages, and social media, the art of letter writing is in danger of disappearing. But I believe that receiving a letter is unique and special. There's the excitement of waiting for it to arrive, the pleasure of seeing who it's from, and the enjoyment of reading the contents. I've been writing letters for as long as I can remember. As a child, I would write notes to my mother, and she would always encourage me to write thank-you letters for birthdays and holidays. When I left home to study medicine in London, I would write to my parents every week, and so would they. My parents would often include news about their friends and family, and I would cherish those letters. I've also received letters from my boyfriends, who were away studying or working. Letter writing actually strengthened our relationships, as it allowed me to express myself more easily in writing than in conversation. I love receiving letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards, as they bring a year's worth of news. I also appreciate airmail letters with beautiful stamps. I have penfriends in Sri Lanka, Australia, and Vancouver, and I've even met some of them in person. One of my penfriends, a lady from France, and I met in a restaurant and have been exchanging letters ever since. We've even stayed at each other's homes. My greatest letter-writing success was when my family and I stayed with my American penfriend in Texas. We had been corresponding for 29 years, and it was amazing to finally meet in person. The local newspaper even wrote about our correspondence. I'm glad to see that my children are continuing the tradition. Like my mother, I encourage them to write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little notes, just like I did to my mother. She and my son have penfriends of their own, arranged by my penfriend. I urge readers not to let letter writing become a lost art.'

The ancient rock art in the French Alps is being damaged at an alarming rate. The site, which dates back 4,000 years, is home to over 36,000 drawings of cows, fields, and gods and goddesses. However, the increasing number of tourists is causing the damage. Some visitors are stamping on the drawings, wearing them away, while others are taking parts of the rock as souvenirs. Some even use sharp objects to scratch their own drawings or names onto the rocks.

Experts are divided on the best way to preserve the site. Some believe that the entire mountain should be closed to the public, except for guided tours. Others think that visitors should be allowed to visit the site, but with restrictions in place to prevent damage. The main problem is that there is no funding to employ enough guards to prevent the damage.

The site was classified as a historic monument years ago, and experts are worried that if nothing is done, the drawings will be lost forever. They believe that a combination of measures, such as roping off the area and providing guides, could be effective in preserving the site.

Here is a simplified version of the text, adapted for a learner of English at level C1:

Shopping with children can be a challenging experience for many parents. One mother describes it as "absolute murder" because her children constantly ask for things they want, such as the latest sugary cereals, Disney videos, or comics. She feels guilty when she agrees to their demands, knowing that the products are not good for them. On the other hand, she hates saying no to her children and feels cross and defensive. Many parents face a similar dilemma. Research shows that children make a purchase request every two minutes when they are taken shopping with their parents. As a result, over £150 million is spent on advertising directly to children each year, most of which is on television.

Children often do not understand why their parents cannot afford certain products, and they may not be convinced by arguments about the negative effects of certain foods on their health. Parents are concerned about what they feed their children and have their own ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always accurate. A dialogue between parents and children about food is important, but it can be difficult when children are exposed only to one-sided advertising.

The Independent Television Commission regulates TV advertising, but even if advertisers are not allowed to directly tell children to ask their parents to buy a product, the intention is still to persuade the viewer to buy something. Parents feel stressed when deciding which demands to agree to and which to refuse. Some parents discuss food with their children and teach them to be critical of advertisements, which can reduce conflict in the supermarket. Others admit that they are inconsistent in their responses to their children's requests, sometimes saying yes to things they know are not good for them.

Supermarkets could help reduce parent-child conflict by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. While parents might spend less if they shopped without their children, the thought of shopping without their children's demands might attract enough extra customers to make up for the difference.

Here is the simplified text for a learner of level C1:

Climbing has changed significantly over the years. In the past, climbers went to mountains to test their skills. Now, you can climb almost anywhere, indoors or outdoors. At the World Cup Climbing Championships in Birmingham, French climber Francois Lombard is hanging upside down from a wall, using only his fingertips. The National Indoor Arena is more famous for hosting the TV show Gladiators, but both events share one thing - The Wall.

The development of climbing walls is thanks to new technology. In the 1960s, climbers used to climb on cliffs, but as the sport grew, they needed a way to stay fit during the off-season. They started using brick-edges and stone buildings to train, which helped keep their fingers strong. Many sports centres began building walls specifically for climbing, using special bricks with edges to grip. One teacher, Don Robinson, built a climbing wall at Leeds University in the 1960s. He came up with the idea of setting natural rock into a block of concrete, which could be included in a wall. This design was copied by many other sports halls in the 1970s.

However, these walls had some limitations. They could only be built vertically, unlike cliffs, which have features like overhangs and angled rock faces. Once the walls were built, they couldn't be changed, and climbers would eventually get bored with the same old routes. In the 1980s, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny developed a material that could be molded into shapes like those found on cliffs. This material could be attached to any existing wall and removed when climbers wanted to try something new. French manufacturers also experimented with steel frames and interchangeable fixtures, allowing for endless combinations of holds and routes.

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a C1 level learner:

So, you want to be an actor? Be prepared for people to tell you it's a risky career. There are many aspiring actors, but not enough jobs. Some friends might think you're crazy for choosing this path. Everyone has different opinions, but it's a personal decision, and only you can take responsibility for your own success. There's no easy way to become an actor - no exams to pass or guarantees of success. It's all about luck, talent, and hard work. However, there's always a demand for new faces and talent, and the possibility of exciting experiences, glamour, and financial rewards.

Talent is often hard to define, but I believe it's a combination of natural ability and imagination. Courage and confidence are also essential. So, why do people want to act? It's often difficult to explain, but the moment of connection between an actor and the audience is crucial. This connection drives actors to keep performing.

When asked how they've succeeded in the profession, actors often shrug and say they don't know. They may have some knowledge about themselves and their techniques, but they never take anything for granted. They know they're only as good as their current job, and their fame can be short-lived. Disappointment is the biggest enemy of an actor. They may have been working a normal job one day and suddenly be asked to audition for a part. However, even if they want the job, there's always a chance it might be denied. Actors often find ways to cope with the stress and possibility of rejection. Nobody likes being rejected, and it's a risk they take from the moment they start looking for acting jobs.

It's up to each individual to care enough about their career and be willing to work hard to succeed. If you don't care, nobody else will either.

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of level C1:

It's true that we're all getting taller. Chris Greener, a man from Britain, is the tallest in the country, standing at 228 cm. This is not surprising, as the average height of people in Europe increases by 1 cm every decade. More and more people are born who are above average height. Interestingly, this doesn't mean we're becoming a new super race. Instead, we're returning to what our ancestors were like 40,000 years ago. 

For most of human history, our ancestors got their food from a variety of sources, including plants and animals. They ate a wide range of foods, including 85 different wild plants. Then, around 9,000 years ago, farming was invented. This had a negative impact on our health and physique. We started eating more carbohydrates, such as wheat, rice, and maize, which left us underfed and underdeveloped. In one study, scientists found that when hunter-gatherers started eating corn, they became sickly and underweight. 

In recent years, however, diets have changed in some countries. In Europe, the US, and Japan, people are eating a more varied diet, similar to what our ancestors ate. As a result, the average height of people in these countries has increased. In the US, the average height is now 179 cm, in Holland it's 180 cm, and in Japan it's 177 cm. 

However, there are still challenges. As people get taller, so do the problems. For example, beds, planes, and trains are not designed for taller people. The question is, how tall will we get? Some scientists think we may reach a limit of 193 cm this century. However, others point out that, although individuals may be getting taller due to better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. 

During the last ice age, our ancestors were slightly rounder and taller, which helped them keep warm. Since the climate warmed up, we've become thinner and smaller, even when well-fed. As the planet continues to heat up, we may shrink even further. This means that the growth of humans could be offset by global warming.<|eot_id|>

|end_header_id|>

**A New Life**

Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in the City of London, but now he runs a sheep farm. After 14 years, he found the City had become too routine and boring. He was made redundant, which was a surprise, but it gave him the opportunity to start his farm. He initially supplied meat to a local hotel, which helped his business grow. Despite the long hours, Matt is happy to have left the office behind.

Ron Ablewhite used to work in advertising, but now he is a full-time artist. He started painting as a hobby, but realized he enjoyed it more than his job. He took redundancy and pursued his passion for art. His career counselor was supportive, and he and his family made a successful transition to a new life in the north of England.

Katherine Goodison was a lawyer for five years before starting her own business making hats in her London flat. She enjoyed her job, but the long hours were exhausting. She left to start her own business, which has been a success. She has to work hard to meet deadlines, but she feels happier and less stressed. She misses the social interaction of her old job, but loves being responsible for her own product.

Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He enjoyed the adrenaline rush, but never felt fulfilled. He took a year off to travel and figure out what he wanted to do. He discovered his interest in health and wellness, and went on to study massage. He is now happy and in control of his life.

'Two brothers, Dave and Norm Lagasse, have turned their childhood game into a successful business. They're sitting in their home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, surrounded by the wooden board and plastic pieces of pichenotte, a game that their grandfather introduced to their family. The game has a long history, originating from India and spreading to Canada and the UK. In Quebec, Canada, it was known as pichenotte. The game is played by flicking plastic pieces across a wheel-like board, aiming to score points by getting them into small holes or around the edges. The brothers started making new boards after their old one broke, and people loved them. They took the game to a sports bar, where it quickly became popular. The brothers researched the game's origins and discovered its history. They started selling the boards at markets and craft fairs, and soon the game's popularity grew. They even created a championship and a trophy. The brothers now make over 450 boards a year in their garage workshop, using birchwood and mahogany. Each board weighs 12kg and costs $595. Although there are no professional pichenotte players yet, the brothers are hopeful that their game will become a global success.'

'Welcome to the Model Village. Just a few years ago, this was a neglected piece of land overgrown with brambles. One person's vision and hard work, supported by their wife, transformed this land into the beautiful village you see today. Thousands of tons of soil and clay were moved to create the unique landscape. Although machines helped, it also required a lot of manual labor. After shaping the land, we brought in 1,000 tons of topsoil to create the lawns, flowerbeds, and rockeries. Over 100 trees and shrubs were planted, carefully selected to withstand the salty air and strong winter winds. Many of these plants came from local garden centers, while others were brought from as far away as Canada and New Zealand.

The village was created by Colin Sims, who spent nine years building the models. Each model is made from different materials, such as stone, concrete, and plastic, to withstand all kinds of weather. Colin worked with experts to learn how to use these materials, and eventually became an expert himself.

You will notice that every detail has been carefully considered, from the scale of the models to the smallest details. This required patience and the development of unique construction techniques. The Model Village has become a popular attraction, known for its high standard of workmanship and maintenance. The techniques used here have even been adopted by other model villages and included in college courses.

The buildings in the village are inspired by traditional British architecture and are not based on specific real places. One of the most impressive buildings is the Manor House, a 13th-century-style stone structure with a brick tower and stone walls. As you walk around the village, you will also see a castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, the latest addition.

Please keep to the paths and do not touch the models, as this could cause damage. Photography is allowed from the paths only, and dogs are welcome on a short lead. To enhance your visit, you can press buttons in front of some working models to make them operate. We value your feedback and would appreciate any comments you have. New models are being planned, and your suggestions will help us create an even more varied and interesting display. We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again soon. Don't forget to tell your friends about it!'

Here is the simplified version of the text, suitable for a learner of level C1:

British newspapers often publish photos that invade people's privacy and break their own code of practice. While pop stars may occasionally pose for paparazzi, this is not typical. More commonly, individuals in the public eye are hurt when their private moments are captured on the front page. Despite this, very few people take their concerns to the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), an organization set up to deal with such issues. Rarely, if ever, are these photos in the public interest. Do intimate shots of pop stars help to prevent a crime? How did a famous actress's hotel bedroom photo protect public health and safety? The actress has complained about long-lens photos in the past, but didn't take action this time either. It's a scandal that the PCC didn't launch an investigation itself. The PCC should also investigate the recent story about a pop star's personal life. The pop star, like the famous actress, hasn't made a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take the initiative on this and other shameful attacks?

To begin with, this seems like a good idea. It would likely lead to many decisions against newspapers. These would be reported by their rivals and broadcast on TV and radio. The public wouldn't be sympathetic, and editors would have to refuse to publish such material. Even photographers would be affected, no longer able to make a living by hiding behind trees to take pictures of unsuspecting celebrities. If the PCC decided to take on this role, there would be several problems. How would it decide whether or not to launch an inquiry? Should it approach the victim and encourage them to make a complaint? And if the person involved still refused to do anything, should it proceed anyway? Additionally, celebrities and members of royalty might expect that any story involving them would be taken up, and then be outraged to find it wasn't. Above all, the role is too enormous. How could the PCC realistically monitor the entire British press: national, regional, and magazines? Then there is the embarrassment factor to consider. Even if someone's privacy has been seriously invaded, would they really want the further embarrassment of an investigation? I suspect the majority just want to put it behind them and move on with their lives. Of course, one or two may have other reasons for keeping quiet. A worse story may exist, that they have managed to keep from the press, and they realize that this may also become public knowledge if they complain. In other words, even the PCC might become the enemy. A British comedian also suffered at the hands of the press when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon in the Caribbean. He didn't complain then, nor more recently, when he and his family were again victims of a sneak photographer during a family holiday. His reason for this was fear that the newspaper, News of the World, would re-run the pictures with a new story about his 'fury', saying that they thought it was just a bit of fun, and that, being a film star who makes comedies, they thought he had a sense of humour. This fear is understandable. People believe they will again become targets if they dare to challenge the tabloids. It's hard to see an easy solution to this serious problem.

Here is the rewritten text, simplified for a learner of level C1:

Many people have advice on what to do after leaving college and starting their first job. This article focuses on those who are considering a second job that aligns with their long-term goals. We're not discussing those who are looking for a temporary job while searching for a permanent one or those who leave a job within the first few weeks. Instead, we're talking about those who have gained some experience, developed skills, and have a clear idea of where they want to go in their career.

When choosing a second job, it's essential to consider your long-term goals. Do you want to specialize in a particular field, take on more responsibility, or move into a broader area? Whatever your decision, you should choose a job that you can stay in for at least two to three years. This job will be an important part of your career development, and it should demonstrate your commitment to your profession.

It's also a good time to consider traveling. You can take a break, work temporarily when you return, and then secure a second job. This can be beneficial for your future employers, as they'll see that you've had a break and are not likely to leave again soon.

Juliette Davidson, for example, worked for three solicitors after leaving college. She found the job to be a good starting point, as it allowed her to learn the ropes and develop her skills. However, there were no opportunities for advancement. So, she decided to take a break and travel for a year. Now, she works as a Personal Assistant to the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. In just two and a half years, she has become more capable and her job has evolved significantly. Her boss has been keen to develop her skills, and her responsibilities have increased. She now handles correspondence, budgets, and various queries from companies and entrepreneurs.

E Kim: I used to be too afraid to speak up in meetings, but I eventually gained the courage to express my opinions. Here is the simplified text, suitable for a learner of level C1:

I visited Malaysia for a kite-flying festival and had a memorable night in the forest. Adnan Ali, a local, gave me one of his kites when it broke, saying it's a traditional custom - the finder keeps it. He showed me his collection of intricately decorated kites made of tissue paper and bamboo. We sat under the whispering coniferous trees at the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, where the biggest and most serious kite festival takes place. The festival features 10 platforms where helpers hold up kites, and competitors wait for the countdown. Over 500 people had registered for the competition, which lasts for five days. Each participant had entered four designs, which are judged on decoration, stability, and flying efficiency.

After the festival, Adnan invited me to visit his home to learn how to make kites. I accepted and spent the evening drinking tea and eating crackers in his large, polished room. The next day, I decided to explore the southern half of the state instead of rebuilding his kite. I drove inland, into the granite mountains covered in rainforest, and took a wrong turn, ending up at a river. A boat ferried pedestrians across, and I noticed a sign pointing to the Jelawang Jungle. Before setting off, I should have known that most of the path was uphill and slippery. However, I met Baba, who ran a tented kitchen and bamboo huts, and decided to stay.

The night was pitch black, with strange sounds all around. A waterfall roared nearby, and I could hear thousands of insects moving and squeaking. The next morning, I woke up to a breathtaking view of five mountain ranges. In the afternoon, it rained, and I got soaked. I slid down the hill, wondering how giant butterflies avoided the huge drops. Later, I thought about my car being swept away and the possibility of drowning if I opened my mouth. Luckily, my car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the track.

In Kelantan, everyone was friendly and curious, asking me questions like "Where are you from?" and "How old are you?" I remember my trip to Kelantan more for its kind people than its kites.<|eot_id|>

I. Linda, a 32-year-old restaurant manager, is an unwilling shopper. She only shops when necessary and doesn't enjoy trying things on or making a fuss."

New Acquisition

It is one of the first paintings of its kind in the Gallery and dates back to 1777-1778. The painting was kindly donated to the Gallery in memory of Ida Nancy by Miss Violet Churchman. It is now on display in Room 25.

Special Exhibition

The exhibition "Painting in Spain during the late 18th century" is now open in the Sunley Room. The exhibition features works by three Spanish painters, Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu, as well as their contemporaries, including Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, Corrado Giaquinto, and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition runs until May 31st.

Lectures

On April 5th, Lizzie Barker will discuss Melendez's work, while on April 12th, Sarah Symmons will talk about Luis Paret. On April 19th and 26th, Juliet Wilson will explore Francisco Bayeu's art. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists often tell stories through their paintings.

Gallery Restaurant

The Gallery restaurant has been improved and expanded, offering a wider range of hot and cold dishes at reasonable prices.

Visitor Information

'Money: What is it? The pound, dollar, or franc are just like units of measurement, such as grams or kilometres. The difference is that you can exchange money for something else. A five-pound note, for instance, can buy a book, a large bag of sweets, or a couple of cinema tickets. However, the note itself is just a printed piece of paper that costs almost nothing to produce. In the past, people didn't have money as we know it today. There were no banks or shops. Instead, people like Mr Green, a farmer, would exchange the corn he grew for Mr Hive's honey. This was a direct exchange between two individuals, each with something the other wanted. Over time, most societies developed their own currencies, making it easier for people to exchange goods. As different currencies began to unite, today we use national currencies.'

Hypatia, the First Woman Scientist

Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 AD. For centuries, she was the only woman to have a significant place in the history of science. Her father, the director of Alexandria University, ensured that she received an excellent education, which was unusual for women at that time. After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia returned to Alexandria, where she began teaching mathematics. She quickly gained a reputation for her expertise in new ideas and mathematical concepts. Unfortunately, we do not have copies of her written works, but it is known that she wrote several important mathematical texts. Hypatia was also interested in technology and invented various scientific tools to aid her research. However, many rulers of the time were wary of science and those associated with it were in danger. Tragically, Hypatia was brutally attacked and killed in the street in March 415 AD.

Ticket prices are: adult £10.00, child £5.00, family ticket (up to 2 adults and 3 children) £25.00. Special prices apply on public holidays.

Nene Park

Nene Park offers a range of activities for the whole family. There are 1,000 hectares of public parkland, including boating lakes, picnic areas, and a nature reserve. You can also visit the miniature railway. The park is a great place to spend the day with your family.

Wansford Station

Wansford Station is home to a unique collection of historic trains from across Europe. You can see famous locomotives like the elegant De Glen Compound from France, the German Class 52 Kriegslok, and '92 Squadron' and 'Mayflower', all built in Britain. The buffet, bar, and souvenir shop are only open when the train is running. There is a small entrance fee of £2.00 for adults and £1.00 for children.

Nene Valley Railway's film history

The Nene Valley Railway has been featured in many films, including the James Bond movie Octopussy. You can visit the station and see where the film was made.

Services for schools

The railway offers special services for schools from May to July, allowing school groups to visit and teachers to set projects. A special educational pack is available for £1.50 plus postage. At other times, school groups can hire the train for a special event. Please contact us for more information.

Private hire of trains

The railway is a popular choice for special occasions or company visits. We can provide a customized programme, including buffet, bar, entertainment, and discos. Contact the General Manager at Wansford Station for more information.

Here is the simplified text, suitable for a learner of English at level C1:

The Ghan Train: A Journey Across Australia

The Ghan train travels from Darwin in the north to Adelaide in the south, crossing the Australian continent. It passes through the desert and the cold Southern Ocean. The train is often called the 'famous Ghan', but it's not exactly famous for being on time. The idea of a rail link between Darwin and Adelaide was first considered in the 1920s, but it wasn't until recently that the line was completed. The railway was built to allow trains to travel at speeds of up to 115 km/h, but the Ghan is not a high-speed train. It has few stops and most passengers are tourists. The train was originally built to transport goods, not people. It was thought that sending goods from Europe to Australia's south via Darwin and the train would be faster and cheaper than sending them around the continent by ship. The Ghan claims to be the world's first north-south transcontinental railway.

As I waited to board the train, I could see that everyone was excited to start their journey. Many of my fellow passengers were Australian pensioners who were eager to travel. Our first stop was Katherine, where the train waited for four hours. Some passengers took a boat trip up the gorge, while others stayed on the train. I didn't leave the train until Alice Springs, where I joined a small group of passengers and a guide for a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock). We walked around the rock and watched the sunset. From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week heading south, so many passengers break their journey here. The view from the train after Alice Springs is not particularly interesting, with nothing to see but cattle. But on the third day, we reached the foothills of an area near the Southern Ocean. My journey was over, and although the train didn't quite live up to its promises, it took me to some of Australia's most amazing sights.

Here is the simplified text, suitable for a learner of level C1:

Climbing Ben Nevis in Scotland Each year, thousands of people climb Ben Nevis, the highest mountain in Britain. Due to its northern location, the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt describes his first winter climb on Ben Nevis. In February, our group decided to climb the north face of the mountain to Tower Ridge, a six-hundred-metre route, which is the longest climb in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are natural bowls cut into the mountain halfway up. We took our tents, sleeping bags, and special metal spikes for our boots, as the snow is very hard and icy. Although some of the group were experienced climbers, we brought safety equipment, including lights, hard hats, and extra clothing. Despite a perfect weather forecast, we still felt nervous as we set out. Ben Nevis in winter is always a challenge. The track soon became steep and my legs felt heavy. As the weakest member of the group, I had to rest more frequently. The others would stop to let me catch up, but then they would continue. I promised myself to train better before a climb in the future. After 200 metres, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the route to the top. It's only a metre and a half wide, with a steep drop on both sides. We knew we had to stay calm and focused as we moved slowly along it. After seven hours of climbing, we reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, 48 kilometres away. Unfortunately, it was misty on our day. Getting down the mountain can be just as challenging as climbing up. You need to be able to read a map correctly, or you might end up on a slope that's too dangerous in winter. I was relieved we took turns reading the map. It was only when I was safe in my tent that I could say I enjoyed the experience. At least I made it to the top.

Here is the rewritten text, simplified to make it suitable for a learner of level C1:

A Letter to the Editor

On Saturday afternoon, I accidentally left my handbag on the bus. It contained my cheque book, address book, purse with £50 in cash and credit cards. When I realised what I had done, it was too late. I was 72 years old, far from home, and extremely worried. I stood by the side of the road, feeling helpless. A young man approached me and asked what was wrong. I explained the situation, and he kindly gave me some money to cover my bus fare home. When I told the bus driver, he told me to keep the fare. I returned home safely and soon received a call from the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus. He informed me that they had found my handbag and offered to deliver it to me. Miraculously, everything was still intact. I would like to express my gratitude to everyone who helped me on that day, particularly for their kindness and honesty. Mrs. B. James, Newport

This remarkable ability has proven useful for researchers who often need to handle sharks, enabling them to gather valuable insights into these intriguing creatures."

Here is the simplified text for a learner of level C1:

THE ICEHOTEL

For many years, the Arctic was a popular destination in the summer to see the midnight sun. But in winter, the few inhabitants had the snow and ice to themselves. In the 1980s, it was decided to make the most of the cold winter weather. In 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit was invited to create an exhibition in a specially built igloo in the small town of Jukkasjarvi, near the frozen Torne River. The building, called Arctic Hall, attracted many visitors. One night, a group of foreign guests decided to spend the night in Arctic Hall, and they loved it. This idea led to the creation of the world-famous ICEHOTEL.

Every winter, a team of snow builders, architects, and artists from around the world come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel. As one part is completed, it opens to visitors and overnight guests, while the other parts are still being built. The first part is finished in December, and each week, a new part is added until the hotel is complete by January 7th. Since the hotel is built outside, the finishing date depends on the weather. In the spring, when the weather warms up, the hotel melts.

Inside the hotel, the temperature is always between -5°C and -8°C, even when it's very cold outside. Guests are provided with warm clothing, such as overalls, hats, and gloves. It's also a good idea to bring extra sweaters, scarves, and warm socks. You can even buy these items on the ICEHOTEL website when you book your visit. They will be delivered to your room when you check in.

The hotel is located in the village of Jukkasjarvi, above the Arctic Circle, but close to Kiruna airport and train station. You can arrange for transportation from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.

Note: I made minor changes to the original text to simplify it, but I tried to maintain the factual content and the original meaning. I also kept the same sentence structure and vocabulary to ensure that the text remains suitable for a learner of level C1.<|eot_id|>

In addition to the competition, we offer educational programs for children and teachers, including the Young Writer of the Year award, which has been running since 1998. Winners receive book prizes and attend a five-day writing course taught by professional writers.

The Writers' Cafe is our social hub, offering a relaxed atmosphere, delicious vegetarian food, and a wide range of drinks. We also host exhibitions, short courses, and readings. This time, she held her breath for over three and a half minutes, becoming the first woman to break a men's world record. A team of 14 safety divers monitored her dive from different depths.

Some people have raised concerns about the safety of free-diving, citing several serious accidents involving other divers. However, Tanya prioritizes safety above all else, emphasizing the importance of proper training. Most free-divers specialize in one or two events, but Tanya's training routine remains consistent regardless of her goals. She uses an exercise bike to improve her cardiovascular fitness, but avoids running to prevent knee injuries. Instead, she finds fast walking to be an effective way to build endurance.

Before competition, Tanya typically travels to a new location and completes 14 dives over a four-week period, with a rest day between each dive. Conserving her energy is crucial to avoid compromising her preparation. When not preparing for an event, Tanya makes public appearances to promote sports products and supports environmental organizations through research projects and films. Growing up on the Caribbean island of Grand Cayman, she spent her childhood swimming and exploring rockpools to observe marine life. Today, she feels like she's living her childhood dreams. As a well-known figure, she believes people are more likely to listen to her concerns about environmental issues. Looking ahead, Tanya plans to continue breaking her own records and doesn't intend to retire from free-diving for many years to come, having started the sport at the age of 25.<|eot_id|>

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of English at the C1 level:

**A Journey Along the Beautiful Douro River**

The MV Lady Ivy May, a 'hotel ship', operates on the Douro River in Portugal. The ship can accommodate 160 guests in double cabins, all with private shower and WC facilities. On board, you'll find air-conditioned public areas, including a sun deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library.

**Itinerary**

Day 1: Depart from London Heathrow to Oporto in the evening. Your guide will meet you at the airport and take you to the ship, where you'll spend the night.

Day 2: Spend the morning sightseeing in Oporto, then return to the ship and depart for Entre-os-Rios. This part of the journey takes four hours.

Day 3: Continue up the river, stopping at Peso da Regua in the evening. Enjoy dinner and sample local specialties, including port wine.

Day 4: After breakfast, take a bus to the ancient town of Lamego, where you'll visit the cathedral, churches, and a museum. The museum, formerly a palace, features an impressive collection of art and antiques.

Day 5: The Douro River becomes narrower, and you may be able to continue to the Spanish border by smaller boat. Alternatively, you'll return to Tua by coach, taking in the scenic views along the way.

Day 6: Drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for a breathtaking view of the Douro Valley. Return to the ship for lunch, then take a scenic train ride through the countryside to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May awaits.

Day 7: Visit Vila Real, then return to the ship for lunch and set off down the river to Oporto. Spend the night on board.

Day 8: Arrive in Oporto in time for independent sightseeing and last-minute shopping before your flight back to London Heathrow.

Although Norwich is relatively small, with a population of around 150,000, it was once the second-largest city in England. Here is the simplified text, suitable for a learner of English at level C1:

The Albuquerque International Balloon Fiesta

Every autumn, the skies above Albuquerque, a city in the southwestern United States, transform into a kaleidoscope of colors. This annual nine-day event attracts visitors from all over the world. The festival began in 1972 as a celebration of the 50th anniversary of a local radio station. Initially, there were just a dozen hot-air balloons taking off from a car park in the city. Since then, the festival has grown steadily. This year, over 1,000 balloons from more than a third of the world's countries are expected to participate.

What to Expect

One of the highlights of the festival is the 'balloon glow', where pilots simultaneously light up their burners, creating a breathtaking spectacle. To witness this, visitors must arrive just after sunset or before 5:30 am. During the day, you can walk among the balloons and chat with the pilots as they prepare for take-off. The balloons come in all shapes and sizes, featuring various designs, from animals to cartoon characters and well-known brands. Kids will love it!

Other activities include taking a hot-air balloon ride over the desert with one of the many companies offering this service. Alternatively, you can take a cable car to the top of the nearby Sandia Mountains, the longest such ride in the world, and enjoy a bird's-eye view of the festival. There are plenty of other attractions for visitors of all ages, including balloon races and firework displays on the opening and final evenings of the festival.

The Albuquerque Box

The unique wind pattern in the area, known as the Albuquerque Box, creates perfect conditions for balloonists. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds, while also creating gentler currents at different heights. Skilled pilots can control the direction of their balloons by rising or descending.

Practical Tips

* Buy your tickets in advance to avoid long queues.
* Wear layers of thin clothing, as it can be cool in the evenings and mornings, but hot during the day.
* Bring a flashlight for night-time events and a camera to capture the stunning views.
* If you're not a digital photographer, bring high-speed film for evening and night-time pictures.

I made minimal changes to the original text to ensure that the factual content remains the same, while simplifying the language to make it more accessible to a learner of English at level C1.<|eot_id|>

The History of Shoes

In the past, people did not consider the comfort or style of their shoes. They wore animal skins tied around their ankles during cold weather. Although leather is still widely used today, other materials like silk, plastic, or cotton are also popular, depending on current fashion trends. It was only about 150 years ago that people started wearing different shoes on each foot. Previously, the two shoes were identical and could be worn on either the left or right foot. Before, all shoes were handmade, but now, although some shoemakers still use traditional techniques, most shoes are mass-produced in large factories. The invention of sewing machines enabled the shoe industry to produce large quantities of affordable shoes for a broader customer base.

Here is the rewritten text, simplified for a learner of level C1:

THE IDITAROD: THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH

In the late 1800s, gold was discovered in Alaska, attracting many people who hoped to strike it rich. A town called Iditarod grew rapidly, becoming the largest city in Alaska for a brief period. However, during the winter months, the town was cut off from the rest of the world due to the frozen rivers and ocean. To overcome this challenge, a winter trail was built in 1910, allowing teams of dogs to pull sleds and transport essential supplies to the town.

The Iditarod Trail was approximately 1,000 kilometres long and took around three weeks to complete. Along the way, the dog teams stopped at 'roadhouses' where the drivers could rest and refuel. The trail was used until the 1920s, when airplanes replaced dog teams as the primary mode of transportation. However, dog teams had one final opportunity to shine in 1925, when a diphtheria outbreak occurred in Nome.

As the closest medicine was in Anchorage, a team of dogs was tasked with transporting the medicine to Nome. The journey was a remarkable feat, covering over 1,000 kilometres, most of it along the Iditarod Trail. The team, led by Leonhard Seppala and his dog Togo, completed the journey in just six days. The final leg was completed by Gunnar Kaasen and his lead dog Saito. Notably, Balto, one of the dogs, refused to continue and saved the team from falling into icy water.

Today, an annual dog sled race is held from Anchorage to Nome, following the same route as that historic journey in 1925. The Iditarod has become known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth.'

Winter driving can be challenging because it's hard to predict what will happen and accidents can occur easily. Fog can suddenly appear over a hill, and hidden ice beneath the snow can cause your car to skid off the road. A car approaching from the opposite direction may also slide across the road. To stay safe, it's essential to drive smoothly and avoid sudden movements, such as turning the wheel, braking, or accelerating. Imagine you're driving with a hot cup of coffee beside you - drive carefully so you don't spill it. Another important rule is to anticipate what might happen. When driving on icy roads, you need to look further ahead than usual and test your brakes to see how long it takes to stop. Remember that you may be going faster than you think, and adjust your stopping distance accordingly. On wet roads, allow double your normal distance, on snow, three times, and on ice, even more. Stay in control of your car at all times, and you'll avoid trouble.

Over a century later, in 1903, the Wright brothers in the United States built the first powered aircraft and took to the skies. The US Post Office introduced the world's first airmail service in 1918. Over the next three decades, aeroplanes underwent significant changes. The 1950s saw a major breakthrough with the introduction of jet engines, which significantly increased air travel speeds. In 1976, the supersonic Concorde was built in the UK and France, capable of flying at 2,500 km/h. This reduced travel times, with the London-New York journey taking just four hours. Today, millions of people travel by air, and it's hard to imagine a world without air travel."

Here is the simplified text, suitable for a learner of level C1:

Visiting the Globe Theatre in 17th-century London was a unique experience. The theatre was circular, with no roof, which meant that audience members got wet and cold if it rained. Despite this, Queen Elizabeth I was a regular visitor, attending performances of William Shakespeare's plays. All the actors were men, and the audience was free to move around, socialize, and even heckle the performers. In fact, some people would throw objects at the actors! Today, it's still possible to visit the Globe Theatre. A modern replica of the original building stands near the River Thames, where you can watch a Shakespeare play or learn about life in the 17th century.

'Dear Jeff,

I'm having a fantastic holiday in Australia. When we arrived two weeks ago, the weather was quite poor and quite cold. However, it's improved significantly now, and we're spending our days at the beach. This week, we're based in Sydney, but next week we're heading to the Great Barrier Reef. The warm water was a delight, and I thoroughly enjoyed swimming there. The variety of fish was astonishing - I saw red, yellow, and purple ones! Australia is truly breathtakingly beautiful. We're having such a great time that we don't want to leave. I'll see you at the end of September.

Best regards,
Sue'
